They had some cool things from Europe which I was pleased to see, but they also had your average run of the mill special candy shop kind of treats----gumballs, gummy bears, licorice,caramels, etc.That being said,I wouldn't say that Miette is THE source of your sweet desires. If you want chocolate, I recommend Bittersweet, and for fudge the sweet shop in Tiburon.


But I echo other reviewers that it was pricey. 
I would be more apt to go to this place if their choclate covered gummy bears weren't so expensive!
author: Kathy K.

description:
A little bit goes a long way and I just consumed my last piece of candy from my most recent trip to San Francisco. Yup, one whole month passed and my fleur de sel caramel still tasted fresh and delicious. I was holding out for that perfect moment. Today. This cold snow flurry day in NJ. The fleur de sel caramel just made it a little bit warmer.

Mmmmmmmmmm. If only you could taste that caramel. It was perfect. I have never tasted a caramel more delicious or divine than the one I bought at Miette Confiserie. It wasn't overly sweet. It wasn't too burnt. It wasn't too light or too dark brown. It was just perfect in every way. Plus it wasn't too chewy and it didn't even stick to my teeth. It gave my taste buds a reason to wake up. It even sent a few signals to my brain. The fleur de sel caramel was the caramel of all caramels. I kinda wish I had bought a few more pieces when I was in San Francisco. Oh well. Next trip.

As I said, a little bit goes a long way. I didn't buy a bag full of candy. I literally bought 4 pieces. Three pieces were Poco Dolce squares and the last was the fleur de sel caramel. Miette Confiserie is a self serve candy store. You can definitely fill a basket with boxes of chocolates, salt water taffy and caramels but you really don't have to. The beauty of Miette is that you can pick just a few pieces to taste the goodness of the overall whole. It's also expensive but worth every penny. The goods here are exquisite!

The store is beautiful. It's simple, old fashioned and elegant. Hell, I even ate my fleur de sel caramel in a dainty fashion. I nibbled. I didn't gorge, inhale and consume. I guarded the caramel in the paper wrapper it came in, I savored every bite and I licked the last taste of saltiness left on my lips. Very slowly, I might add. 

This is a candy store for grownups. So for God sakes please. Do not run in screaming and demanding someone to buy you gobs of candy. Respect the sugar.
author: Rachel A.

description:
Oh those Miette caramels ($0.75) are amazing!!!

I picked up a cupcake for my little sister who was flying in for a visit. I got the chocolate cupcake with the buttercream ($3). It was really good! I don't know much about cupcakes, but I know when I like something and I definitely liked this one. It also gave my sister a yummy first impression for San Francisco.
author: Mariko F.

description:
I like their macarons. They're expensive though, so I like them best when someone else buys them for me. 

Luckily, it's not a craving I need to satisfy. 

Very cute store, looks like a modern take on something that would named Ye Olde Candy Shoppe. 

Pass on the cakes. They were ok but not fantastic.
author: Erika C.

description:
I visited Miette on a Friday at noon, (right when they open), and if you haven't been inside before, it's worth the visit.  There isn't really a word to describe it, other than "CUTE."  The shop has tables of jars filled with candies and baked goods.  Everything is so colorful and so pretty.  

I came in to pick up some gingersnap cookies for my mom, for Mother's Day.  She absolutely loves ginger-y cookies.  And when she tasted these, she agreed with my assessment, that these were "as good as gingersnaps could be."  They are really quite ginger-y; so if you like ginger, then it's worth a try.  You get about a dozen cookies for $7.  

The service was helpful and quick.  I probably shouldn't be eating so many cookies, but I'm sure I'll be back soon.  I saw a sign that said that macaroons were only $1 from 5-7 (i think); so I'll have to follow up on that.

Notes:
-The gingersnap cookies are on the 7x7 list.
-You can't buy only one cookie, but that's okay, you'll want to eat all of them anyway.
-Parking in the area may be difficult, you just have to get lucky.
author: Samantha L.

description:
I heart CANDY. I like chocolate, I like wine, but I LOVE CANDY.

This doesn't make me feel like the most sophisticated person in the world.

You can occasionally see me cracked out on sour, sugary candy.  At the cinema, there I am with my $5 box of Sour Patch Kids. Long day at work, and I often have my coffee and bulk sour candy sitting on my desk. That's just gross, though.

Miette makes me feel that's it's OK to looooove candy!  Yesterday's trip VALIDATED and AFFIRMED my love. Artisinal salt water taffy, French lollies that I loved as a child, Swiss chocolates that I liked when I studied there! Yay....Miette makes me feel tres sophistiquee...Until I leave and I am the ONLY adult sucking on a lolly on the Octavia Green.
author: Joanna M.

description: My sister bought me 3 of their cupcakes and they were all sinfully delicious. My favorite was the Old-Fashioned which is topped with a marshmallow icing. I also sampled the chocolate with coffee buttercream and chocolate with vanilla buttercream frosting and rainbow sprinkles. Cupkate's is still my favorite place for cupcakes, but Miette isn't far behind.
author: F K.

description:
An absolutely cute little shop from both the outside and in. Tons of enticing selections at reasonable prices. All around great candy shop that is a few notches above the rest.

The Chikki is spicy and delicious.
author: Zack F.

description: yum. Great place in Hayes Valley for chocolate and candies. Macarons were LSO good.
author: Xteethx B.

description:
Miette needs no introduction with me, I am a loyalist!

In typical miette style, it is adorable and whimsical. The staff is very friendly, sweet, and attentive. Such a delectable place with walls & tables lined with jars and jars filled up with candy confections and display cases of macarons & cupcakes. And a cotton candy maker on the side. And potted gumdrop "plants" (where does one buy this! Please do tell!)

I was hoping to see signature miette candies & chocolates, but didnt. Nonetheless, i was really impressed with their candy choices, even offering candies that I've only seen in England. They had violet gum & mints, earl grey & green tea chocolate bars! I really wanted the mushroom shaped gift box, they are so so so so so so so cute! I could spend all day here! If you feel like you deserve a treat, you should definitely pay a visit here.

lovelovelove this place!
author: Stella C.

description: Got a dozen macarons for about $21.  They were delicious and not too sweet.  I'd have to say my favorite flavors consisted of the pistachio, and vanilla flavors.  There was also a large assortment of candies, baked goods, and ice cream sandwiches to choose from, but we didn't try any of those because we had a large craving for macarons which did not fail us.  Whew.
author: Patty O.

description:
Cupcakes can be hit or miss but everything else is stellar.

Lavender shortbread is one of my faves, along with their fleur de sel candies. 

Their selection of fancy chocolate bars has been expanding it seems... once I find myself with 12 bucks to burn on a bar of chocolate I'll be getting one for sure. 

Love the decor and product displays too - makes you want to explore what is in every jar and bowl.
author: Liz K.

description: When you walk in this store all your troubles are put on pause as you are transported to a magical place.  You have now walked into the best candy/sweets store ever.  Everything is so nicely presented down to the tiniest detail and the interior design is oh-so-cute!  Decor aside, the candy and sweets are delicious.  I'm a particular fan of their Scharffen Berger cake - a gorgeous looking, decadent and rich chocolate cake that is moist and dense in every wonderful way.  I love coming here because it always puts me in a good mood.
author: Lisa K.

description:
I love stopping in here to pick up candies and sweets as gifts for friends and family members.  And occasionally a treat for myself!

Some old fashioned candies, unique licorice from around the world, Jelly Belly jellybeans, cupcakes, cakes, cookies, suckers, chocolates, malt balls, sour ribbon... those are just the tip of the iceberg on what you can find inside this incredibly pink store.

Today I stopped in to pick up a few gifts for family (a tin of chocolate "sardines" for my dad! HA!) and treated myself to an absolutely amazing ice cream sandwich.  Sitting at the park across the street in the misting rain and enjoying every bite, I really felt like I was in heaven.  

This is a great place to stop by for treats and some great candy and baked goods.  Highly recommended!  The quality is worth the price!
author: Cassandra J.

description: Great candy shop.  The kids had a fun time here.  The ice cream cookies were excellent.
author: J R.

description:
For Christmas, my secret santa gave me a container of their graham crackers.  I just opened them a week ago.  They were freaking amazing.  Seriously, the best graham crackers I've ever had.  I don't know what they put in them but I was not sharing.  Not, nope, not sharing at all.  Step away from my crackers!

I have not been to the actual store... yet.  But since it's in my hood, I'll be by very soon.
author: Ryan B.

description:
Holds two of my favorite foods in the world: cupcakes and macarons. Cupcakes are hit and miss - the yellow cupcake was dry but the gingerbread cupcake was moist. Macarons never fail. Their packaged pound cake was delicious and lasted for days too. All sweets lovers will love this place.

JONASAPPROVED!
author: Jonas T.

description: French macarons.  Divine.  Enough said.
author: Kim S.

description: Totally indifferent help, store is run by 15 year hormonal girls.  Took a cab ride to the store to please my kid, who saw Miettes book at MOMA, spent $60 on sweets. My kid asked to use their bathroom almost in tears, and the boss (16 yr old) told us to go down the street at a bakery.  As for their sweets, which one would expect cakes, they had 3 different 4-6" cakes in the room temperature display, we bought 2 and they were OK, but that is all.  Best thing were the overpriced macarons, but still not worth the aggravation.
author: Daniel U.

description:
Just back from Paris. Went to Ladurée. Miette has SPOILED me with macarons, I just felt sad and wanting more Miette instead of enjoying the Parisian macarons.

The real reason Parisian women are so thin? Their macarons are not as good as Miettes.
author: tamera f.

description: Cute candy, cupcake and macaroon place. I've been here and to the one inside the ferry building. Cupcakes and macarrons are good and cute, I wouldn't say phenomenol though.
author: Linda H.

description:
Handmade toffee's and candies are awesome.

repackaging swedish fish and other candies not so awesome.

I am in love with their Englilsh toffee and will probably suffer from a heartache or acute diabetes from it but it's my decision and I am an adult.

Anyway, why this place is not in Pac Heights is beyond me. This is a kids and breeders wet dream.  Everything looks like out of a book. And they make cotton candy to order?

Dr. Seuss couldn't of wrote a better candy shop.   

Just remember where you are buying the candies and you won't leave the store crying over the bill.
author: Spanky M.

description:
Miette Confiserie is utterly lovely - exponential eye candy at the tip top of the scale. Like an impressionist painting mixed with sugar plum fairies, tutus, satin ribbons and pastel rainbows. It's pretty. Very, very pretty. 

They offer cotton candy in a "flavor of the day" (that's special). I chose a beautiful box of champagne gummies, BF made off with a pound (!!!) of rock candy. Macaroons abound with their circular seductiveness . I'm still miffed at myself for failing to try one of their gaspingly cute cupcakes. What was I thinking?

It's sweet. It's delightful. Miette manages to limbo just under the threshold of cloying. Four fancy pants stars.
author: wendella a.

description:
Oh Miette. If only I could afford to visit you more often. If only your salted caramels weren't $1.50 apiece.

Despite the high prices, I still go (more frequently perhaps than my wallet would like). Miette is such a treat. That wall of licorice, and the lovely cookies, cupcakes, and delicious salted caramels always keep me coming back for more!
author: Alexandra L.

description:
I can go in here and say, "I'm like a kid in a candy shop" and in this case there is candy galore and I geek every time i walk in. I'm not sure if its the layout and the way that the colors of the candy pop from the white walls but it makes me happy.

You can get all types of classic and imported candies that you thought was extinct. From assorted flavored cotton candy to chocolate. Do yourself a favor and get yourself a macaroon!
author: Stephanie Rose P.

description: This was the first place that I had ever had the pleasure of trying out french macaroons. And since then I have never found another spot that competes with Miette's macaroons. Pistachio and the chocolate-lavender are just heaven!
author: Michelle I.

description: Omg. A candy Disneyland for adults! Everything they make is perfect. Great service too.
author: Lucy P.

description:
Oh, Miette, you definitely know they way to my heart is through the stomach. 

This place is cute, the decor alone makes you feel like a little girl in a candy shop. 

I tried the Fleur de Sel Caramel, Chocolate Fleur de Sel Caramel, and the pistachio, lavendar, rose and vanilla flavored macarons. I loved them ALL, but my least favorite was the rose, just because I'm not too used to it yet, I'll have to try it again during my next visit.
author: RoseMichelle M.

description:
I am in love with their cute decorations. The moment I walked inside, it feels almost as if I had walked into the world of "happiness" and "joy". The colors are so bright that you feel like you can never get depressed. 

These are what I got:
-Gummy Bears
-Lime Meringue Tart

The graham crust was delicately put combined with the filing of lime cream topped with sweet boiled icing. One word....."divine" Absolutely love it and the flavor is light and so addicting! From my first experience I would so go here again!
author: Cavin T.

description: I'm the kid in THIS candy store! My Miette must haves? The gingerbread cookies, fresh marshmallows & macarons of course. It's always nice to come in and browse their selection to see what else can accompany my usuals in that sweet little pink bag.
author: Stephanie D.

description:
S O  C U T E. 

I came across this little beautifully cute candy shop/bakery while waiting for a table at Stacks one morning. I'm a sucker for great decor, cute concept, and nice people! Miette has it all. I used to bring people in just to look at how cute it was inside, but the consumer in my finally succumbed and now I'm a fan of their products too, lol. I'm not a big fan of the candy, but their baked goods definitely caught my eye.

Although I am not a big fan of macaroons in general, their macaroons were good! They tasted cakey and delightful, all organic and artificial dye free. Also from 5-7 on weekdays, the macaroons are only $1 instead of $1.75, not a bad deal! 

Also, I LOVE cotton candy, and they serve it fresh! However, they have seasonal flavors and currently it is rose/germanium. The nice sales girl suggested that I try a cupcake instead. My guess is that they will be switching that flavor out soon. 

Speaking of cupcake - best advice the nice sales girl could ever give me. The old fashion cupcake with meringue frosting was SO DELICIOUS. Not to mention, its a great gift cupcake because it looks absolutely perfect.

The ladies behind the counter are super sweet and nice and make the buying experience all the better!
author: Sarah A.

description: I want to like Miette, I really do.  Its really, really hard to not like a candy place, but unfortunately, Miette comes close . . . Let's start with the prices:  They are outrageously high.  I mean, I know candy is a splurge and all, but really, ten bucks for a bag of malt balls?  Yikes.  And then there is the staff:  Haughty, aloof and not at all fun.  This is a candy shop for goodness sakes, not a fancy art gallery.  Have some fun guys!  Finally, the store itself:  It is "cold as ice" and not in a cool, trendy way.  It just feels sterile to me.  I still love the malt balls in the pastel colors, but I'll settle for boring milk chocolate ones purchased at the fun, friendly and warm candy shop in my neighborhood.
author: D H.

description:
Super cute sweets shop in the super cute area of Hayes Valley. After hearing so many great things about this place, I decided to come by and check it out for myself. The first time I came here, I got ginger snaps and a macaron. The ginger snaps are really, really, amazing. Ginger snaps are probably my favorite cookies ever. They use three kinds of ginger in their cookies, candied, dried and fresh ginger, I think. It is soooo buttery and soooo crispy. Yum Yum Yum Yum Yum. Pretty darn good deal for 7Bucks if you ask me. 

I also had their lavender chocolate macaron and it was pretty good. I'm actually not a big fan of macarons, I've come to realize. Meh

The second time I came here, I got the ginger snaps (of course) and picked up one of those salted caramels that people have been raving about. Honestly, its good, but not 1.50 good. I was actually pretty disappointed. The texture was good, but the flavor just didn't really do it for me. 

Also, both times I've been here, the cashier girl seems really unenthusiastic. You work in a friggin sweetshop for god's sake! Why are you acting like you can't wait to get out of there? lol

Will come back for Gingersnaps and possibly shortbread.
author: Mindy H.

description: OMFG, they have happy hour and instead of drinks you get Macarons for a buck each. The store is adorable and if I brought my niece here she'd probably just stand there in awe. I know I did. A useful tip is to not bring a friend who is a foodie enabler cause they'll just agree that you do need that extra cookie.
author: Theresa D.

description: Oh my, it's been so long since I've been to Miette, but I still can remember how awesome it was when I first stepped inside... Truly a boutique confection connection, I adored the selection of sweet treats both nostalgic and new. Great customer service, delicious treats and novelties... and gummy smurfs. That's right, gummy smurfs... and a nice assortment of licorice candies which I never knew I had an inkling for until Miette.
author: Fatima M.

description:
Best french Macarons ever!  If you go after like 5 or 6 pm, they are half off.  That's when I decided to splurge and try a bunch of them.  Even one day old, they were still delicious.  I really liked the hazelnut flavor one the most.  

The rest of the shop is REALLY cute.  So many colorful candies and treats.  Definitely felt like a big kid in a candy shop.  Just kind of hard to go crazy here because nothing is exactly cheap.  It would be really fun to have a shopping spree here and feel like a kid.
author: Anna T.

description:
Their store is so cute! So many sweets, which I think are pretty pricey.

I ordered their Gingerbread Cupcake & a couple of French Macarons. The Gingerbread Cupcake was moist & flavorful! I absolutely loved it! The French Macarons was good as well. They have a butter-cream filling which is pretty good. I would definitely come back get their cupcake & French Macaron.
author: Christina L.

description:
This place has some good treats for sure. They have a lot of hard-to-find pre-packaged candies and sugary snacks, many of them foreign. Their baked goods taste somewhat fresh, and they claim to use natural ingredients, etc.

But if you decide to come here, be prepared to spend $8 for a mini stack of home made graham crackers, $12 for a small bag of chocolate almonds, or $4 for a mediocre-tasting cupcake.

Yeah, this place will cost you a arm and a leg. Not that the products are not good, but it's basically a run-of-the-mill bakery/candy store trying to cover their high lease payments in the trendy lower Hayes neighborhood.

Is this a crime? No. But they are an institution attempting to capitalize on a fat hipster's wallet who just got drunk off $12 beers from the beer garden across the street. Like I said; nothing wrong with this. Just be prepared for their skyrocket prices. Don't get me wrong. I have absolutely no problem with paying for fine pastries that I think are worth it. But I just don't think this place is worth it.

I actually liked this place for a long while. But here's what really made me balk at this place after being a loyal customer for a long time...........

So I walk in here with my gf on a Thursday evening, July 5th, at 6:30pm. We had been used to purchasing their macaroons at "Happy Hour" prices on weekdays from 5-7pm for $1 for a long time. Good deal right?

So we come in here and order a bunch of macaroons. The lady rings us up and tells the total cost at normal price. 

Me: Wait, aren't the macaroons $1 during your advertised "happy hour?"
Lady: We ended that deal last month.
Me: Well the offer is still being advertised on Miette's official website.
Lady: Oh well we haven't updated our website in years.

The lady says that and looks at me like I'm stupid. Uhhh, is it MY responsibility to be up-to-date on the Miette website's latest updates? Am I, the consumer, the one who is wrong because YOU have not updated the website "in years"?

Now, it's not the price that got me ticked. It was really the non-existant customer service, coupled with the woman's utter lack of politeness and rough dialogue, that made me mad.

Please don't come here unless you want to be looked at like a giant wad of cash waiting to be spent.
author: Max G.

description:
Before my dinner at Il Borgo I stopped by Miette Confiserie and it was still open.  That was cool.

There were many new candies that I saw.  Their candy can be really cheap like .25 a piece of hard candy from Holland, or almost $20 for a candy bar.

This time got 3 things:

Gianduia 1865 Caffarel $1 a small piece - gold wrapper, tasted fine. Similar to the blue wrapper one.

Gianduia fondente Caffarel $1 a small piece - blue wrapper.  Tried this, it's a rich, creamy, chocolate hazelnut candy.  Very smooth.

Caffarel Eccellenza Piemontese Pure Cioccolato Gianduia $5 - yellow wrapper from Italy. - Haven't tried yet.

They have some turkey wrapped chocolates - very cute.

My total was $7.  Credit cards taken.

Hrs: Daily 11am-7pm
author: Ann L.

description:
Miette, Macarons, & Me

Five years ago, I spied the seasonal Lavender Chocolate macaron at Miette in the ferry building, and I discovered the wonder of macarons: a TRIPLE TEXTURE cookie! Crunchy exterior, chewy interior, and smooth, creamy filling. On top of that, the macarons came in splendidly exotic, floral flavors, like Rose Geranium. From then on, I was hooked [obsessed]. Since then, I've dabbled in macaronage in SF, NY, and Japan, and Miette remains one of my two favorite sources for macarons in the city.

What makes Miette better than the rest?
*The Triple Texture never fails! They are never stale like Bouchon's, and the cookies are sifted less finely than Chantal Guillon, so the slight graininess gives Miette's macarons the chewiness that Chantal's lack. (Plus, because of the textured appearance and lack of coloring, Miette's macarons come across as being very natural...almost healthy! A good excuse to eat them.)
*They have floral flavors that are appropriately delicate in taste. Chantal Guillon's are overpowering in comparison, or even without comparison.
*The prevailing filling is unique: Not just smooth and creamy, but also light and delicate! One previous reviewer mentioned that they use buttercream icing. I've never had this type of filling on a macaron anywhere else.
*AMPLE filling. They may cost $1.75, vs. Chantal's $1.70 and Bouchon's $1.50, but you get more bang for your buck.
*Wait, what's this, a Macaron Happy Hour, 5-7pm M-F? $1 per macaron for some of the best macarons in the city? Oh my. My inner goddess rejoices.
*What they could do better: Give me your seasonal flavors year round! *love* Oh yes, and provide cute gift boxes, not Chinese take-out boxes. Please, I have enough of those already in my fridge.
*Random storage tip: You may store boxed macarons for 1-2 days in the refrigerator.
*More on Miette: By the way, you might want to check out Miette's ice cream sandwiches as well if you like flavors like Earl Grey. They also have candies in unusual floral flavors as well, such as lavender drops.

[Stop 3 of 4 on my Macaron & Liquid Nitrogen Ice Cream excursion in Hayes Valley.]
author: Fawn B.

description:
This is an update to a review I wrote  quite awhile ago. Miette has lost its charm. It's magic.  The stock has become sparse and not very interesting. The last cake we had there was dry, dry, dry.  Sad loss.


My first review:
Take a walk back into your childhood, kiddies! Miette is a treat for the eyes as well as the palette.

Oh, and when you see that your favorite sweet is in a giant jar tagged  "$8 per pound" and it seems pricey, stop and realize just how much a pound of candy is.  It's a lot! (1/8 to 1/4 of a pound of my favorites usually do me.)

Check out the salt water taffy, salty black licorice options, gourmet chocolate bars, and various imported treats.

The only down side: for awhile it smelled like fresh paint in here: understandable for a new shop. Now, it smells like chemically, wafting plug-in air fresheners. Not very appetizing.
author: Heather S.

description:
I can't imagine what else I could possibly add to all the comments below. Miette was eye-pleasing, the staff was friendly, and it was mega fun running around and drooling over the stuff. I got salted caramels-- I had bought my boyfriend one to give him when I met back up with him at our hotel but my secret shame is the first two were so good I ate his and didn't mention it to him. Shh. My friends squealed when they happened upon a Lion Bar, which is apparently fairly hard to come by in the states. "It's what a peanut butter Twix wishes it could be." said my friend. I bought one. And it is. 

Looking at photos today from my trip to SF I saw the few I took of Miette and immediately began craving the salted caramels. The mere fact that two months later, I still remember that candy says something, I think.
author: Danielle G.

description:
I currently live in NYC but grew up in San Francisco and will be getting married this fall.  I have always loved Miette, from their macaroons to their cakes.  Since I will be having my reception in SF, I had my heart set on getting my wedding cake from here.  I didn't even have any other options - Miette was going to be it.  

I've been in contact with the woman who handles weddings since February 3rd (i'll be nice and will refrain from mentioning any names).  They are very limited with the customizing, since they don't have the staff to support a gigantic custom wedding cake order.  She gave me the option of doing a 3 tier cake with the disclaimer that it may be difficult to do but it's been done before.  After 2 weeks of emailing her back and forth (mind you I had to resend a couple of the emails because she didn't respond), she finally tells me that she's going to forward me to the head pastry chef to see if she can accommodate my wishes.  The pastry chef emails me and and gives me her number.  I called her and left a message and emailed her the next day giving her my number.  Another week passes - I still haven't heard back from her.  Since the initial conversation on Feb 3rd (it's now Feb 27), I've also been trying to schedule a tasting with them since I'm only going to be in town for one weekend before my wedding date.  Never was I given an appointment for a tasting.

I know they have limitations and I was willing to work through all that.  All i wanted was my wedding cake from Miette.  I would have even gotten multiple cakes instead of one big wedding cake, if that wasn't feasible for them.  My fiance and I are extremely disappointed and saddened by this.  I am taking this very personally because everyone else seems to have received such great service from them and I was barely even given the time of day.

I WILL BE TAKING MY BUSINESS TO CAKE COQUETTE.  Gabby's customer service is impeccable.  She emails back within the day and I already have a tasting appointment with her.  That's very impressive being that she makes the cakes as well as runs the business.
author: Rica S.

description:
Love, love Miette Confiserie. In the heart of Hayes Valley is Miette Confiserie, a small boutique candy shop. Reminiscent of a youthful time, this shop is decorated with bright shades of blues, greens, and pinks.

I found myself lusting after the simple yet delicious looking Vanilla Tomboy cake. It kind of reminded me of an unfinished cake but it was beautiful, in a understated way. Cupcakes and candy are also other items that Miette sells but Miette definitely has an upperhand in the European cake styles. This shop is a guarantee crowd pleaser for all ages!
author: C M.

description: My favorite macaroons in SF. After having Laduree in Paris, it's hard to like any other macaroons. When I moved to SF, I went to every place in the city and tried every flavor of macaroons. Miette is definitely my favorite. Usually vanilla is not the flavor I like, but their vanilla flavor is to die for, as well as the rose one.
author: Mrs V.

description: Miette is a very special shop. Walking in to Miette makes me happy; the decor, the colors, and the sweets, of course, are perfection.
author: Annie G.

description:
Such a cute little shop!
For $1.75/macaron, these better be good. My friends and I found ourselves here after learning that Paulette's would be closed for a couple days due to limited supplies? WHAT DOES THAT EVEN MEAN!?

Luckily, we were able to stumble upon Miette's - success! We got the hazelnut macaron along with a box of gingersnaps. 

The macaron was to die for - so delicious. It wasn't so sugary like a lot of the macarons I've had before - it was just right. Good hazelnut flavor shined through without being masked by sugar.

The gingersnaps are good as well although I can only half of one at one time - too spicy for my taste. But $7 for 12 cookies, are pretty good that way since it'll take me a while to eat them!
author: Julia K.

description: when I step into this cute little shop, it brings me back to my childhood days. scrumptious french macaroons and extraordinary (note: they also offer happy hour!) my favorite flavors... pistachio, vanilla, and hazelnut), out of this world candy (choco malt balls are highly recommended)... how can you go wrong? so, check this place out after a meal at stack's or patxi's!
author: Ann T.

description:
holy crap Yelpers...this place has gotten many reviews! talk about some serious sweet tooth here! This place is right next to a very famous breakfast place that I won't name because it doesn't need any more publicity that it already has.

I walked in here for the first time and thought I died and gone to sugary, syrupy, high fructose corn syrup heaven..where the angels fly on wings made of marshmallow and God is really a dentist, eager to fix your jacked up teeth after you eat way too much candy. yes, it is expensive, but this ain't no Snickers candy bar yo! Their french macaroons are the smaller version, at 1.75 a pop. It is nice, BUT.i still gotta say that the ones in Bouchon Baker are still top dog in my belly. They have a great assortment of Rose flavored candy, from rose candy drops to rose chocolate. We spend some major bucks here, but it was all worth it. Just ask my belly..it growls with agreement.
author: Jerry C.

description:
Loads of sugar in its most glorious, adorably packaged form. From fleur de sel caramels to cupcakes, chocolates and taffy, the displays are uncluttered and colorful. 

I definitely lack the discipline to eat just one of their pistachio macaroons: crisp outer surface, soft gooey interior. And the buttercream on the cupcakes is fluffy and just sweet enough. 

Good gifting potential also. Though gents should watch out, the place is so freakin' cute just entering it may lower your sperm count.
author: Ligaya T.

description: I was super excited to visit Miette for their yummy treats. The Schaffenberger, in my opinion, was WAY too much chocolate for a dessert, if that's possible! The cupcakes seemed like they'd been out for days. The icing was okay though. The macaroon I tried, rose geranium, was interesting. Very perfume-y, maybe in a good way? I haven't decided. I probably won't return, but it was worth a try.
author: Tiff H.

description:
I love you Miette!

Seriously I just LOVE things in Jars. i love your taffy "cigars" and your homemade cotton candy that you let me sample for free. I love your amazingly crazy but shockingly delicious chocolate covered lentils. I love your sweet staff, who dole out samples of things you'd never tried before. I love the obscure old school candies you sell. I also adore you for carrying all the different colors of M&Ms I needed for my wedding and special ordering me several pounds of the colors you didn't have in stock, charging me a fair price for this service.

I was so close to licking the wallpaper to see if this was real-like wonka world!
author: Nikki M.

description:
i love love love miette. everything they have here i want to buy and eat. 
the decor is adorable and the candies/treats here are delicious.

for such a charming store, i am surprised that despite the many times ive been here i have not encountered the staff as equally as charming or personable.
author: Jennifer T.

description:
#49 on 100 Things to Eat Before I Die in SF: Ginger Snaps

So, after our luscious Tacolicious lunch, we see Miette right down the street and it's a mad dash to kill two birds with one stone.  

We head in and are the only ones there, to stir the magazine-reading confection princess behind the counter.  I say, "We're here for the Snaps - you got 'em?"

"No, unfortunately, we're sold out."

WHAT?  Wait, whAT?  No, WHAT??!!!

The grace of God saved that girl as my friend piped in that there was another location at the Ferry building.  A little farther, but totally doable.  Then we learn that they've got another location in Hayes Valley.  Score - closer!  Then I ask if she can call beforehand to see if they've got 'em.  They do - they have four left.

Then, I'm like, "Guys, they only have 4 left!  We gotta get the hell outta here and there before everyone who's doing this list today like we are head for Ginger Snaps!"  

Come on, it's entirely plausible and you know it.

We get to the Miette on Octavia, I double park.  They head in.  They come back out with a canister of these things!  No wonder princess on Chestnut looked at me crazy when I pushed down that little girl to get out the door to get back to the car.

We open.  We taste.  It's damn good.  Then we get the brilliant idea that they'd be AWEsome with ice cream.   Wait, there are two ice cream places on THE LIST: Humphrey Slocombe and Bi-Rite.  

Oh yeah, we're making this happen.
author: Tamar D.

description:
Stepping into Miette Confiserie, I feel like I've stepped into a painting.  Or an old school movie.  I just want to run about with a sparkly pink dress and feather boa and sing "Pure Imagination" from Willy Wonka and the Chocolate Factory (the original-- not the scarily-notsohotforonce-Johnny-Depp version).  Okay, maybe sans the feather boa.  But definitely in the sparkly pink dress.

I come here mainly for the macarons, which are, of course, scrumdiddlyumptious.  I have also tried the gingersnaps (on the List) which are super gingery but addictive LIKE CRACK.  Everything else looks wonkalicious, too.  Ok, I'll stop with the Charlie and the Chocolate Factory references.  But really . . . 

There is a wide assortment of chocolates and candies from Europe, which is pretty awesome.  Be forewarned-- the prices are not cheap.  But you're paying as much for the image as well as for the goods themselves.  And, as I like to say, sometimes you just need to indulge!  The cakes, the cookies, the candies-- they even have homemade cotton candy (flavors like grapefruit, etc.)!  The cupcakes and cakes . . .?  Think Wayne Thiebaud . . . :D
author: Jeanne Y.

description:
So adorable. This Miette location (and only this one, I was told) has a "happy hour".  $1 macarons every weekday from 5-7pm. I got the hazelnut macaron and it was amazing. 

I've also received their ginger snaps before as a gift, which were good for the pre-packaged variety. I would not get it for myself though. Do yourself a favor and get a macaron, or three.
author: Richa A.

description: Cutest sweet shop ever. Note to self: bring Mom here!
author: Rosanna R.

description: My mom found Miette on a day trip to San Francisco and knew their dragees would make the perfect favors for our event. We ordered about 100 bags of them (sugar coated almonds in adorable pastel colors) and they came looking just beautiful, like something out of Alice in Wonderland. Everyone absolutely LOVED them, we put custom stickers on the bags that read "Sweet thanks, love Moni + Billy" and they were a hit. Thank you, Miette team, for contributing such a special touch to our wedding!
author: Monica F.

description: You may have used the phrase, "Like a kid in a candy shop." but really when was the last time you were in a candy shop? Do you know how it really feels to be in a candy shop? Being in the candy aisle of Safeway is not the same thing because 1. the candy at Miette is so much better and 2. at Safeway there's also baker's chocolate and unsweetened coconut shaving in the candy aisle, which is gross. Everything at Miette is amazing.
author: Javier S.

description: Goodness this place is heaven on earth. Its tucked away in such a cute little botique looking candy shop, across from Patricias Green ( and the pop-up Ritual coffee stand!) so It a must to pop in for there decadent graham cracker (which taste more like creme brulee if you ask me) and stroll over to Ritual. Ive had their salted caramels, chocolate cupcakes, and their creme friache ice cream sandwhich and reccomend them all!!!!!!
author: Nicole M.

description:
Miette Confiserie is soo cute! Its like being a little kid in a candy store and Miette IS a candy store! They also carry cupcakes and cakes -- their old fashioned cupcake looked really good but i forced myself not to buy one since i ate cupcakes the previous night.

I will definitely come again :D
author: Carol Y.

description: Heaven! Best cupcakes ever, and friendly staff to boot. Can't believe I only discovered this place today....
author: Miss M.

description:
Unabashedly cute and girlie...gives me a toothache just looking at the place. When they say it's all about the presentation, Miette is Exhibit A. They carry a mixture of American and European confections and everything is displayed in glass jars, hurricane lamps, dainty little dishes and other acoutrements that just make you want to buy them all. 

Admittedly they are overpriced (0.75 for a nickel sized chocolate ladybug for example), but for someone looking for certain European sweets not easily found on this side of the pond, it may be worth it. I picked up chocolate, vanilla and hazelnut macarons, graham crackers, vanilla bean marshmallows, fleur de sel caramels and a couple of other bagged goodies. Overall the quality of the confections does not disappoint. Go ahead, be a kid in a candy store and treat yourself to something pretty.
author: Gigi V.

description:
For their macarons.....

I took a bite and thought "This is not a macaron"
Tried the vanilla and rose ones.  Completely the opposite of french macarons.  The shell was a very chewy dense thick almond cake that was very sweet.  The filling was a very thin layer (thickness of a dime) of an icing of sorts.  If I had fillings, it felt like chewing the macaron would take it out.  I'm not a fan at all of these.  I would much rather have a traditional macaron.
author: Q L.

description: I am glad I ate my first macaron here! It just melts in  your mouth. At $1.75 per piece it is definitely pricey, but I don't mind indulging once in a while :)
author: Priyanka A.

description:
Very cute shop with baked goods and candies! Service was great and so were the macarons. 

So the thing about the macarons is that they're a bit more rustic than others. That is, they're not perfectly smooth like many you see these days. Instead, they are uneven and have rough edges, and are fatter than most. In addition, the macarons are also a bit drier than normal, and very chewy. I loved the texture, though the flavors are pretty average.

If you want something a bit more perfect, try Chantal Guillon, which isn't too far from this shop. Their macarons aren't as dry or chewy, and don't have that rustic look. Also, their filling is very soft, which was something I didn't enjoy too much. Still, while I prefer the texture of Miette, the flavor of the Chantal Guillon macarons cannot be beat.
author: Sydney E.

description:
Martha Stewart and Miette have ALOT in common. Both pride themselves on producing upscale and immaculate indulgences. Both have perfected the presentation of packaged sweets and treats. Both create high quality confections that are easy on the eyes and pleasing to the palate. And both charge a pricey penny for their perfect products. As a Candy lover I have to ask....... is it really worth it?

For me Martha and Miette have always been just a bit too perfect.  Candy is playful, colorful, messy, and fun. It should be a sweet, simple indulgence - not an expensive one. I love treats that take me back to my childhood and remind me of the many carefree and comical moments of my life. I don't remember pretty packaging or pastel pink paint - but I do remember painting my lips pink with lollipops. When it comes to sweets I have simpler tastes and a much smaller purse - I'll stick to the timeless treats I can afford to eat. I've found the Marina's Sweet Dish offers a much larger variety of treats at prices that can't be beat. Both are beautiful stores - but I love being able to pay less for more!

Miette is beautiful - I admire and respect the owners for creating such a sophisticated and stylish store. It is definitely worth visiting for the superb service and adorable retro decor. Perfect place to find a petite present or splurge on a special treat. I know I'll  be back for a gingersnap and their special Sherffen Berger Chocolate cake. But for me - I've got to go somewhere else for candy !
author: Caroline J.

description:
Fiance took me on a macaroon hunt through SF. We made our way to Paulette Macaroons, Miette, and Patisserie Philippe. 

We literally ordered almost every macaroon flavor each place had to offer (I've been happily munching on them since Saturday) - but we decided to base our macaroon showdown on 2 basic flavors (rose and chocolate) and 1 flavor that was special for that one location.

Results?

Can we say TOTAL KO.

Hands down, knock out. The chocolate was SO good at Miette. While Paulette and Philippe had very good chocolate macaroons too - it almost felt like their macaroons were for the milk chocolate lover while Miette had a  chocolate macaroon for a dark chocolate lover, and I am a dark chocolate lover.

The rose macaroon was another Miette knock out. The rose scent hits you right before you take a bite and there's this subtle rose flavor that's intense without being overpowering. (Philippe's rose macaroon tasted good too - but in a artificially flavored sort of way). 
 
The special flavor? No need for one. Hands down winner.

If I HAD to be picky - maybe a few more flavors would be nice (5 flavors last Saturday) and another way to differentiate between all the macaroons would be nice too. Don't get me wrong, I appreciate the "no artificial flavoring' feeling since they don't color their macaroons - but the result is usually the macaroons are beige with the slightest tint of color. Good thing the rose macaroon was so fragrant because there was no way I was differentiating it from the pistachio one... lol. 

P.S. - the rose macaroon was my favorite macaroon of the day.

Oh, while I'm at it - try the CHAMPAGNE GUMMIES. It's expensive at $10/lb but they are SO good.
author: Karina G.

description: Came in sorta late on v-day so I didn't get to check out their cupcakes or anything. There were 4 flavors of macarons then-- chocolate, chocolate orange, hazelnut and vanilla. They were delicious and not too sweet. The shop is also very cute with all sorts of sweets, although kind of pricey. I bought the lemon verbena hard candies just because I thought the color was cute. The flavor was alright, wish it lasted longer because after a little while, it just tasted like plain sugar.
author: Allyson L.

description: Cute store, great customer service and their macaroons are the BEST!  I really wanted to buy everything in the store, but then I'd go broke from all my dental bills!  If you're ever in the area, you MUST visit MIETTE!
author: Melissa T.

description:
Brought my kids, sister and nephew here late in the afternoon, lured by colorful pictures of dainty pastries, and candies displayed in nostalgic glass jars.  Wow!  Zotz --  the individually wrapped hard candy with a fizzy middle!  I remember those.  Ooh, watermelon.  Let's get some!  Wait, why is this one all sticky?  Wait, they're all sticky.  Did they put these out in the sun?  Hmm... how long have these been sitting here?

That's okay, not everybody likes Zotz.  Let's go look at the pastries everyone's been yelping about.  Oooh, so pretty!  Wait, is that a fruit fly of the family Drosphilidae which thrives on fermented fruit?  Look, he has three friends with him salivating over the cakes.  

Smile at the nice lady behind the counter and backpedal away from the store.
author: Karen Z.

description: Great cupcakes.  Place is Frou Frou (actually, I think it's more cheesy) and not my style... And you probably will not find me going into this place again but hey, I won't say no to a cupcake from Miettes! They were delicious.
author: Aban E.

description:
Miette is like the grown up version of Mr. Bulky, the mall candy store where my siblings and I would splurge on a big bag of candy corn or our favorite single flavors of jelly beans or whatever else sounded good and tooth-rotting that day.  At Miette, you have elegant glass jars instead of clear plastic bins, and your tooth-rotting flavor of the day will set you back slightly more than your adolescent pocket money indulgences.

There are a couple of things that I found noteworthy about this particular Miette location.  First, the shelf of Dutch licorice, arranged in order of saltiness.  I'm not a big licorice person, but I was encouraged to sample, and left with a wee packet of several different kinds of new-to-me licorices, including one that looked like a sugar cube but had the texture of a marshmallow.  A small, intense licorice marshmallow.  Perfect.

Second, this Miette sells Idaho Spuds, a bar I'd only read about (in Steve Almond's Candyfreak) until spotting it on the the table.  I'm not sure if I'd endorse the bar itself, but I was pretty excited to see it in Miette's selection.

Long story short: I'd have many more cavities if I had regular access to Miette.
author: Elizabeth E.

description: I LOVE MIETTE! i'm a sucker for presentation, and of course, the store is completely adorable. it's got that fun, colorful candy shoppe vibe, which i LOVE! i could almost spend hours in here just looking at everything and taking it all in. but enough about the decor - i'm a sucker for sweets, too. i heart the cupcakes too. they're so moist and the buttercream frosting is just perfect. my current favorite right now is the gingerbread. the cream cheese frosting is delectable. yum!
author: Caroline I.

description:
Miette is so cute.  It's the type of candy shop that you would have seen on an episode of Pushing Daisies (RIP) or the location of some musical number in a movie musical.  It's adorable.  The prices are a little high, but for the quality of some of the sweets I've tried there it's so worth it.  

The cupcakes were too cute to pass up (even though I may or may not have had a mini earlier that day).  I tried the chocolate cupcake with the meringue.  Before I say anything about it, let me get out my gripe.  Gourmet cupcakes these days frustrate me.  There are some delicious exceptions, but on the whole they tend to be overpriced and all looks and no substance. That being said, the Miette cupcake was delicious.  Perfect all the way through.  

I also tried one of the macarons (What? I was recovering from a final).  Texture-wise, they were different from other macarons that I've tried.  Not in a bad way, but it certainly was different.  I tried a bite of my friend's lemon and the hazelnut.  I loved the hazelnut, but I'm also a sucker for all things hazelnut.  

And I suppose I can't not talk about those ginger snaps, can I?  It's actually been a while since I've tried this one, but oh man they are delicious.  A must try.
author: Alea G.

description:
$1 macaron happy hour, 5 - 7 pm, every weekday.

living just three blocks away can get kinda dangerous sometimes.
author: stefanie h.

description:
Walking into Miette is like stepping into a party thrown at Amy Atlas's home! (She's the Queen Bee of candy bar displays, for those unfamiliar...she is BUH-NANAS)  This location is so cute!  It's a nice small sized shop which gives it a really intimate feel.  

The candy, of course, is displayed beautifully throughout the shop.  They have a ton of options, ranging from run-of-the-mill chocolates you could find at a corner store (and low prices to match!) to high end items from chocolateries and other specialty stores...one chocolate bar was over $10!

Even if you don't want to purchase any candy or cupcakes, it's totally worth stopping by just to see how amazing thoughtfully displayed candy can look.
author: Bunny R.

description: ugh. Went here today to buy my daughter an after school treat. We bought a few candies and 3 different cupcakes. I just ate my chocolate cupcake with plain white buttercream frosting. It was likely the lamest cupcake I've ever paid for. First of all, the cupcakes there are very small in size. Second, the pile of frosting on top looks pretty in the display case but is not functional. It is piled way too high on top and not to the edge so it's pretty hard to get frosting in every bite (or you get only frosting bites) which I find very undesirable. Moving past appearance, let's talk about the actual taste: the cupcake was very dry with flaky crumbs and the frosting was one giant clump that just fell off after a couple of bites. Both of these things are cardinal signs of an OLD cupcake. I would guess it was at least 2 days old if not more. There was nothing moist about it whatsoever. The chocolate cake was drab and the buttercream was super bland and boring. It didn't even taste like vanilla. I am a fairly decent baker and I know I can make a better quality cupcake any day. Betty Crocker from a box is likely more appealing. You should be embarrassed, Miette, to sell these cupcakes in your fancy looking storefront. Go to Sift on California and take a lesson in what a top notch cupcake should be!
author: EStar M.

description: I love macarons!  And Miette's are the best.  I prefer them to the macarons at Chantal  Guillon, right around the corner at Hayes Valley.
author: Marnie S.

description:
My son and I came here for stocking stuffers the other day. The sales clerk focused on rearranging three cupcakes in the display case while we stood there waiting (She was about three feet away, facing us. The nearly empty display case contained the three cupcakes and one Buche de Noel). 

We were the only people in the store, but it took her awhile to look up. When she did, she said "hi." No smile, no welcome, nothing else. I said "hi." And then after an awkward pause, she said "can I help you" in a voice that clearly indicated that she really didn't want to help us at all. 

I politely asked her for a pound each of three different types of black licorice. It took her at least 5 minutes to bag the candy. 

During that time, a very pleasant woman arrived and cheerfully commented that their cake display case was nearly empty, saying "wow! what's the occasion?" 

The woman behind the counter said (in a monotone and slightly mean voice) "It's the holidays." The friendly woman stopped smiling, turned and left the store. 

I wish I had done the same. 

The sales clerk rang up my order, took my credit card, and didn't say another word. For $56 I expect some facsimile of pleasant, if not speedy, customer service. 

I am sorry that I  was trying to save time and didn't go to the Candy Store at Vallejo and Polk. They are wonderfully welcoming, very helpful, and great at customer service. The black licorice is also $3 less per pound at the Candy Store. And they have a better overall selection of candy. 

I will never darken the door of Miette again. If you're looking for cakes, there are also many tasty and friendlier options in this fair city.
author: Jill H.

description: Macarons! Oh yeah! I got two pistachio, two chocolate lavender, a rose and a raspberry. Don't expect colorful macarons here, as they are not dyed. Even though they are not pretty, they do taste beautiful, fresh and flavorful.
author: Cindy T.

description:
Fabulous.  Not cheap, just fabulous.

Very cute store with some of the best baked goods this side of Paris.  It's become my go to place when I need an outstanding cake for a special occasion.

Candy selection is impressive and includes lots on unusual French imports.  Having grown up in Paris, makes me happy to buy them, even if I don't recall paying quite as much when I was 6 years old spending my allowance money to do the same.
author: David A.

description:
No exaggeration here--someone should make a movie about me and Miette. It can be titled, "Me and Miette."

Miette has a endless selection of all candy colored like spring and easter; it needs nothing more than a patch of grass with flowers and sunshine. I wanted to skip around, smell the goodies, relish in the simplicity of candy!

I couldn't stay away from the cupcakes--after contemplating for a full 5 minutes on which flavor to get, I settled for the old-fashion chocolate with Italian marshmallowy frosting. It looked so fluffy and endearing with that small red button nose. 

My cousins got a stash of British chocolate. Though they tasted fine, it's better to just go with the things made in the store. Everything is a little pricey, but all the items have a value of uber-cuteness that cannot be paid with a dollar.

If only the gum drop decorated stand was really edible--then it would truly be my wonka-chocolate-factory dream come true!
author: Hana J.

description: Maybe because I had an incredible flavored macaroon at Chantal Guillon (salted caramel--you're welcome) that just makes the two I purchased here not even stand a chance. at all. Yes the macaroons are a bit bigger and fluffier but it's all about the flavor and I wasn't impressed.
author: Sandy T.

description: More licorice advice for true fans... do NOT get what they recommend or what they say is their best seller.  Americans do not usually like licorice and this recommended candy will be bland, stale and not taste very strongly of licorice.  Go the extra mile and taste the licorice ahead of time before you buy.
author: Jean K.

description: My husband and I were so excited to try this place. It had great reviews...someone even compared it to Lauderee. However, aside from the lovely decor it was awful! The location off Octavia was so weird. The staff took over a minute to even notice we walked into the store, and we stood at the counter watching both employees on their phones for what seemed like an awkward eternity! The candy was all packaged cute, bit the macarons were nothing to write home about. No colour, lack luster flavor, and the rose flavored one literally tasted like my grandmother's perfume ( it could have at least been a cute color!!). We will not be back, and will never recommend this place.
author: Jennifer S.

description:
Cute little candy shop. A bit expensive, but they have good foreign candies.

Only accepts credit cards for orders over $5.00.
author: Jessie B.

description: Super cute pastry/candy shop. Went on a Sunday after seeing a book about this place in Barnes & Noble. So many varieties of candy, cute macaroons (pistachio) is my favorite one, and I got the chocolate cupcake with Italian meringue. Which was very good, not dry, reasonable price. My brother got the ice cream sandwich that was good too. Friendly staff :)
author: Jeanie Ann D.

description:
If a baby rainbow exploded in a store it would create Miette Confiserie. 

Confused? Don't be. This candy shop is filled with delicious treats inspired by nostalgia & the finer things of life. Pure decadence. 

Things to try:

Macaroons 
Salted Carmel 
Mast Brothers Chocolate 
A bucket full of Jelly Beans
author: Nathan M.

description: Outrageously expensive dried up French commodity candies. And some homemade stuff I didn't try...
author: Bobby T.

description:
RIP Miette on Chestnut Street.  I can't believe it's now closed.  How can that be?!  Why didn't anyone tell me?!  Clearly, I'm still in denial.  That location was my favorite.

Still, there are two other places in the City to get my mac(aron) on.  I'm a fan of the rose flavored ones.

Save room for dessert at Miette when you're in Hayes Valley.  And get your own macaron.  Not suitable for sharing.
author: Jenn C.

description:
People have told me to get the macaroons, or sandwich looking pastries. The cream was pretty good and the cookies were nice and soft, but it wasn't mind blowing good to me. I think I have tried better ones. Is there something else I should try? maybe that will change my ratings. 

But over I think 2.5 stars for the taste, and .5 stars for the cute-ness. hehe
author: Phuong V.

description:
i happened to be staying down the street from this disgustingly adorable little sweet shop and was there every day of my trip. i didn't see any of SF, only the inside of miette.

i feel guilty typing out 'disgustingly adorable' in this review because there's nothing disgusting about miette. yes the walls are so pink, the entire store is painted in eye-rolling worthy baby hues, and you're afraid to touch anything bc it's all so cute and delicate, but i still want-to-lick-everything. 

i came for one thing as i'm sure most do: the macaroons. and not just any macarons, but the cheap macaron happy hour (M-F 5 -7 pm). they were $1 each, decent size---which i know isn't saying much for macarons which come in standard sizes of: i can't believe i paid that much for so little, why?!, and what-the-fuck.

the flavors aren't anything crazy, your usual chocolate, lavender, almond, pistachio, coffee, lemon, etc. i believe the flavors rotate so perhaps there are others. 

rumor has it they've perfected the vegan macaron...peace out texas.
author: Melissa N.

description: Why is the phrase "kid in a candy shop?" I am an adult and I enjoy sugary confections just as much if not more than any child. Not to mention I appreciate places that have unique sweets such as a black licorice section, lavender shortbread, and cola flavored Mentos more than any child would. Not only are there baked goods such as cakes and ice cream sandwiches, but a variety of chocolates, stationary, and cake decorations as well. It's definitely a fun place to come but prepare to dish out some dough as some of the treats are pricey. I enjoyed this shop; I was like an adult in a candy store.
author: Kim S.

description:
Stumbled upon a sign pointing to Miette after Sunday brunch today at Suppenkuche. 

First impression: cute overload!!!!!!!!!!!!!! (in a good way).

A hazelnut macaroon. MM good. $1.50 a macaroon. 

5 cupcakes... $3 per cupcake.

Also got a peach flavor taffy candy. $2.00 a candy. Apparently, the company that made the taffy has been in business for over 100 years (as mentioned on the descriptive card next to the candy)  so P wanted to try it.  P was also saying how he wanted to buy a $15 chocolate bar because of another very persuasive card description. Those darn cards!  :)

After paying and receiving all my treats in a nice cute bag, we stepped outside to a park and sat there on a bench, indulging in cupcakes and taffy candies. 

Vibe: lovely Sunday indeed.
author: J T.

description:
Miette, Miette, how I love Miette....

One day I wandered into a new candy shop that had just opened in Hayes Valley. There were jars or candy, table tops loaded with chocolates and a case filled with cakes and cupcakes. As I walked up to the counter and asked for an Old Fashion cupcake, the sales person swung herself around, hair flowing while she glided across the floor in a fairytale dress. She scooped up two cupcakes and placed them in a box. I fell in love. Chocolate all over my face. I was definitely having a Disney moment. 

To this day, Miette is one of my favorite shops. If you haven't been, you must go. Yes, it can be a bit pricey, but I am willing to pay for quality.... and Miette does not disappoint.
author: Jon P.

description:
Before I moved away from beautiful San Francisco, I lived two blocks from this little place, which is situated right upon Hayes Green in the middle of the neighborhood. It is absolutely one of the places I miss most about the city.

The place: adorable and Willy Wonka-esque. I almost licked the wallpaper.

The candy: always new stuff, always a mix of inventive (BACON CHOCOLATE!) and the traditional, like the imported Italian dark chocolate bars made in some tiny Italian village, the story of which was printed on a cute little tag in front of the display.

The staff: they know their candy. They can help you find whatever you're craving, and always give helpful suggestions. You can tell they love their jobs. And why wouldn't they?

Every time I visit the city I spend close to $50 on a care package of candy from here - for myself, of course! :)
author: Nick A.

description:
OMG DID I JUST DIE AND GO TO HEAVEN?
Miette on Octavia is a freakin' CANDY SHOP.
A cute cute cute cute CUUUUTE candy shop.

You walk in, everything is white and pink. There are shelves that are lined with clear glass jars, all filled with sugary sweets. There are tables to your right and left, all covered with more sugary goodness. 

I do have to take off a star for their not-so-tasty macarons. I believe that there are other places that serve up less chewy macarons.
1) Paulette which is down the block.
2) La Boulange which is across the street.
For those who say Miette has better Macarons than Paulette, either you like uber chewy macarons and I like ones that melt in your mouth and have a slight chew to it, or something is quite off with your judgment. Trust me when I say Paulette makes thee BEST macarons in San Francisco. BUT COME TO MIETTE FOR CANDY!!!
author: Heidi C.

description:
I'm a sugar hog and finally came to grip that sweets are my delicious little forms of kryptonite & I'm surrounded

So knowing that Miette's was a couple blocks down from work just made life a little more challenging but a lot more easy too =)

Since trying the macaroons (at Paulette's) for the first time & having enjoyed them. I decided to have my own little taste off and tried Miette's macaroons and the result...divine.

Unlike Paulettes macaroons, Miette's had a lot more texture, nuttier & not too sweet (in my preference, that's good). I tried their Chocolate Lavender, Almond and Chocolate. Paulette's was too sweet, however, it's bigger & more attractive with the vivid colors. But bigger isn't necessarily better as they say (though, quite the contrary on my Specialty's review)

They also have other little imported goodies...so yummy to try and cute in the eye. Like the chocolate sardines in a can and creamy mint sticks

I have yet to sink my teeth into their popular carrot cake which my co-worker gladly gave a thumbs up to

I'm not into the pink & crème colored walls in zig-zags, dots, circles but the little kids would love it...it's like being in a dollhouse. 

For me, the décor is hypnotizing but I think the sweets managed to that for me in itself
author: Charmian D.

description:
Cutest, Sweetest Store in the city. I absolutely love their decor, it's like Marie Antoinette meet Willy Wonka. They have tons of high end chocolates and assortments of Malt Balls and Jelly Belly.

I empty my wallet here all the time, so I can't go there too much. Miette makes life wonderful. And they are always very nice and helpful.
author: Valerie T.

description: I feel like a little kid in a candy shop.  It's the most whimsical , most adorable, most likely to meet your sugar craving type shop.  From old school candies to macarons, this place has something for the sweet tooth.  The staff is very nice and welcoming.  I love the buttery shortbread cookies and gingersnaps.  This is the perfect place to get someone a thank you gift or just because or maybe just get something for yourself.  Also on weekdays if you come in after 5pm the macarons are $1 each!
author: Ro C.

description:
This place is adorable! Cute little candy shop..

I decided to stop by Hayes Valley just to try Macarons from here and Paulette macarons. Everything was so cute, I bought some bon-bon candy as well to try for the first time. I ordered the Rose Geranium and Hazelnut flavor Macarons. The filling didn't seem proportionate to the outer shell. The outer shell was a bit too much; don't get me wrong it was at least fresh and chewy with a bit of crunch. It was good to try, but I don't think I'd be back for more.
author: Nancy L.

description:
Caramels all sorts: chocolate, salt (sea salt, gray salt, etc.), burnt.

Ginger snaps! 

Maple bacon lollipop.

Black licorice mustaches.
...............................................................

Side story: One time I was here and a mom with three kids walked in. She announced to the kids (and the rest of the store) that the kids could have anything they wanted! *so jealous*
author: Jacquee P.

description: What happened to all the great staff? Attitude and poor customer service, I bought the cookbook and I'll make it myself.. It's too bad.
author: John R.

description:
256 reviews of Miette and every single one mentions how cute the store is. Well make it 257. This store is adorable. And it's filled with CANDY! 

Sweets from around the world, candy from your past, jars and cases full of deliciousness. But what caught my eye were the cupcakes. Some people balk at spendy cupcakes but you see, I have no problem paying $3 for a cupcake because I figure I don't eat them that often, might as well get a good one!

As for the cupcake itself, it was good, not great. The icing was nice but a bit rich for my taste and piped so high it was hard to take a bite with both cake and icing. The vanilla cake was tasty though.

I'll definitely come back to Miette the next time my sweet tooth starts acting up...I'd love to work my way through some of the more exotic treats that they offer. Or better yet, this is the perfect place to pick up a little something for that certain someone special*

*now accepting applications for that certain someone special.
author: phil h.

description: Smaller than expected. Cute little place.
author: Bayarea K.

description:
UPDATE:

I spoke with the assistant manager , Crystal, at Miette, and she was incredibly apologetic and sweet.  The transaction had actually been voided, but had not shown up on my account yet (it did, three days later).  

As for the poorly handled transaction, Crystal spoke to the owners and even to their credit card companies to create a new policy which protects eveyone (including honest customers). She was very kind and on top of it.  She even offered gifts to the kiddos if we would come back in (which we did not accept, but only because getting free stuff for complaining sounds like a bad example to set for the girls).

I have to say I was impressed by how hard they worked to try and make up for our bad experience. I can't give them 5 stars because, well, they made my girl cry, but they were very decent about it afterward and ,really, the place does have some very tasty sweets.

============================================

Horrble horrible experience. I will never, EVER be back.

Sunday, the sales person at Miette made my four year old cry. I am not kidding.

We were vistiing my daughter's sweet little friend who lives in the neighborhood (and her lovely mom).  As a treat, we took them both, plus one other 4 year old in to buy candy and to order 10 cupcakes for a dinner party I was having that night.  The kiddos were very good and super excited to have the pretty little suckers they found. It was actually impressively sweet how good they were. They even waited patiently for 15 mintues while the lady behind the counter filled our cupcake order. 

We got to the cash register and the lady ran my card and all was well...then (AFTER charging me) she asked me for my picture ID (something that had never been asked of me in the 3 or 4 trips there prior).  I looked for it and found that I had taken it out of my wallet (later to be found at home). Despite the fact that I had (1) been there several times before and waited on by that specific lady, (2)  I was with a woman from the neighborhood they knew, AND (3) I was with 3 pre-schoolers who had waited patiently for their chance to have their promised candy... she said "Well, we have to be careful." and refused to sell to me.  

Well, I shoudlnt' say refused to sell it to me. She refused to give me my purchase. She apparently had no problem charging me $40, as it showed up on my card the next day.  I called and they have yet to call me back to refund the money.

My daughter took it well, but on the way home teared up a bit she was so disappointed. I will never ever go in there again and encourage you to avoid it as well.  Any place that holds itself out as a happy place for  children but is willing to hurt their feelings in a way that flies so in the face of reason does not deserve your business.   

Go to the Candy Store in Russian Hill or Sweetdish in the Marina.
author: Shannon W.

description:
(staring, mouth open, drooling from the outside looking at the cupcakes)
"it will be mine, oh yes, it will be mine"
author: Alex H.

description:
I love this place! It's just off Hayes, and I have my old roomie to thank for introducing me to this sugary sweet gem! This place is so cute, and love how they have all of their sweets arranged. Everything on display is so neatly organized and stacked that you don't want to touch it to mess it up. Many of their candies are in glass jars throughout the store. Since 'V' day is approaching, there's a huge section devoted to the holiday with all kinds of chocolate hearts, etc., The middle table has the exotic and hard to find chocolates, like Vosges 'Mo's Bacon Chocolate Bar' (which, by the way is pretty good)! 

My favorite part of the store is actually the counter area, where all of the cupcakes, chocolate tortes and cakes are displayed. Additionally, there are jars of macarons on top of the counter - JACKPOT!
Of course, I have no willpower, and bought a cupcake and macarons. The ginger spice cupcake was heavenly, as the cake was super moist, and the frosting was so rich and creamy! I have to say that this is in close competition with my beloved red velvet from Marita's as my all-time favorite cupcake. The macarons were absolutely divine, and are my SF favs! They have the perfect texture and sweetness level, and must buy at least 4 whenever I come here. A super friendly lady helped me and  recommended their special grapefruit flavor. I wasn't totally sold on it at first, as I usually stick to the caramel, hazelnut, coffee, or vanilla, but was open to trying something fruity. Man, I'm so glad I listened to her, as the grapefruit is now my fav! YUM! My worry is that I'll crave it now, and the next time I go there, it won't be available as a new special will take its place! *Did I mention the cute packaging and wrapping that this place has for all of their candy and baked sweets? I almost asked for another bag, but didn't. 

Anywho, the friendly Miette staffer mentioned that  another location will open on Chestnut very soon. Looking forward to checking that out, as well as returning to this location.
author: Gill C.

description: I love everything about this store, its the adult Willy Wonka (and they even sell Willy Wonka) lots of English goodies you can't get a lot of places. The seasonal selections and displays are my absolute favorite store front in all of San Francisco. The Rose macaroons can turn any cloudy sky blue. I love love LOVE this place.
author: Lyndsay R.

description: The macarons have good cookie flavor but the filling could use more flavoring.
author: Retired B.

description:
I am absolutely in love with this place. I've stopped by a couple times for their chocolate covered gummy bears (one of my favorite candies of all time) and I love that I can buy by the pound!

I have yet to try any of their macarons or cupcakes, but I do have a weakness for both.

The atmosphere is so quaint, French and incredibly girly- It's straight out of some storybook or dream. I can't help but get giddy when I come in here- it's the perfect sweet shop!

Seriously... this is the place to take me to melt my heart/put a smile on my face
author: Felicity M.

description:
macarons- I tried one here and I don't want any other dessert.  Seasonal flavors too.  I also bought a really expensive chocolate bar ($12) for my bf, and he loved it and savored it.  I think the experience is worth the cost.  
Friendly staff.  Lots of jars of candy, old school and modern.
author: Candace B.

description:
Tried some macarons on my last visit....They really aren't the traditional French macarons since they don't use blanched almond meal. And the almond meal they do use is not ground to a find consistency which makes them VERY chewy...not melt in your mouth like the ones you get in Paris. It was a good cookie, but I love the "real" macarons that dissolve in your mouth with a velvet texture, like the ones you can get from Paulette across the street.

Bottom line: Miette for cupcakes, cakes, and candy. Paulette for Macarons!
author: alexandra r.

description:
This Miette location is more of a candy store and it's so pretty inside! Makes me want to go crazy buying candy, but I don't think my dentist would like that. 

A and I were heading to Domo for my birthday dinner #2 when we saw the sign for Miette. A got crazy excited (and I do mean CRAZY excited), grabbed my hand and we beelined it to Miette. He spotted the glass containers on the counter filled with super yummy macarons and told me to pick the ones I wanted. My absolute favorite macarons for my birthday snack? That is so super duper awesome!

So I chose hazelnut, pistachio, vanilla, and chocolate orange. They also had chocolate and rose, but I decided to only get four. My favorite had to be the pistachio. The macarons are $1.75 each, which is a bit pricey, but that's why I don't have them everyday.

I heart Miette macarons (but not as much as I heart A)!
author: Kris L.

description:
I got no beef with Miette. Any negative sentiments on my part, honestly, stem from a suppressed envy/jealousy of the girls that work here and my own desire to be the cute, hip girl that works in a really cute candy store.

Having spent a good portion of my life living in France, I am not too thrilled with their macarons. Of the ones that I've tried, I find the fillings to have that sort of greasy aftertaste indicative of too much butter. So that is really too bad.

BUT their coconut cake is so so good. I've also had their princess cake and have to give props for their fondant, which somehow manages to not taste like garbage (like most fondant does). And the gingerbread cupcake! Sigh...

I prefer the confiserie to their ferry building location for the wider array of candies from all over. My most recent discovery is a milk chocolate bar infused with rose geranium. It is amazing. I die.
author: Deborah H.

description:
Never been here but someone brought me some macaroons.

The chocolate was good but the vanilla ones were POW!

Summer camp brownie consistency, light but dense, with not over sweet smooth vanilla creme.
author: Isaac L.

description:
This place is wonderful! The best location of all of them becuase they have a wonderful assortment of candies, cakes, cupcakes, etc. The best part is that everything comes in a wonderful little package. Its perfect for gifts!

I went it and they were soo helpful putting together an engagement gift! Awesome customer service!
author: Julia S.

description:
The Miette folks have struck gold - or at least sugar - again. A very cute store harkening back to a more innocent and playful time, with gourmet chocolates from all over the world and plenty of tempting candies and sugary treats as well, it's hard not to smile when paying a visit.

I was there this past Saturday afternoon, and the place was swarming with youngsters and oldsters alike. For San Franciscans afraid of the drag of getting old, you can quite literally feel like a kid in a candy store (although there is nothing childlike about their prices).
author: Nish N.

description:
Stepping into this place, I felt like I was transported into a pastel pink Willy Wonka-esque wonderland of treats.  My senses were so overwhelmed by all of the different types of candy - chocolates, caramels, etc. in all different varieties and flavors - that I ended up only getting a gingerbread cupcake with cream cheese frosting.  Boo . . .what was I thinking.  That cupcake was damned good though.  It was so pretty with a cute little sugar flower on top, ultra moist, and the frosting was creamy and delicious.

Some of the goodies seemed a little pricey.  One cherry cream truffle cost $3!!   I guess the way to do it is to sample one or two things per trip to keep the spending on lock down a little.  Only problem is deciding what delectable treat to try . . .
author: Jenny R.

description:
Who can take a sunrise,
Sprinkle it with dew?
Cover it in chocolate and a miracle or two...
The candyman, the candyman can,
The candyman can 'cause he mixes it with love
and makes the world taste good...

Who can take a rainbow,
Wrap it in a sigh?
Soak it in the sun and make the stra'bry lemon pie
The candyman? The candyman can...
The candyman can 'cause he mixes it with love
and makes the world taste good...

The Candyman makes
everything he bakes
Satisfying and delicious.
Talk about your childhood wishes.
You can even eat the dishes!

Who can take tomorrow,
Dip it in a dream?
Separate the sorrow and collect up all the cream,
The candyman? The Candyman can, the candyman can...
The candyman can 'cause he mixes it with love
and makes the world taste good...
And the world tastes good
'cause the candyman thinks it should...
