If you don't end up with this song in your head as you browse the lovely offerings at Miette Confiserie, you are dead inside.  

I turned all Veruca Salt up in here:

I WANT IT NOW!!!!!

I practiced restraint only because I was with my skinniest friend who is satisfied with 1/4 of a gummi bear. . ."Oh, that's my sugar for the week."  Die, bitch, die!!!!!

Ahem . . I digress. . .I cannot wait to take my goddaughter here. . it's truly a wonderland of sugary goodness.  

They have some baked goods including cupcakes so perfect that they don't even look real.  They also have their macaroons . . .however they were sold out of them by the time I got there.  Their macaroons are perfect.

Fancy candies from around the world including one I hadn't seen in the longest. . .the Curly Wurly!!!  I can't wait to tuck into that one.   Luscious hand made caramels flavored with Blue Bottle Coffee or Fleur de Sel.They also have an enormous selection of licorices for those of you with the warped palate that enjoys that kind of thing. . .

Speaking of warped palates. . .they have my beloved chocolate covered gummi bears.  The good kind.  Fresh as can be.  Delectable!

- one star for not being vegan friendly . . . willy wonka would have hooked a girl up!
author: Lainie L.

description:
holy cow, this place is freaking adorable! Sure it's a little on the pricier side, but it's highly specialized, niche marketing, so I don't really fault them for that.
Last time I was there I came back with earl-grey tea chocolates, lavender shortbread cookies, and a chocolate cupcake with raspberry frosting that was completely amazing.

Also its in a wonderful location, with a small park next to it that people take their dogs to play at. My roommate and I got our sweets and then sat in the park watching the puppies and enjoying our treats. It was wonderful and I can't wait to go back.
author: Lin B.

description:
Sun., Nov. 11: Sassy S. consumes 1 chocolate cupcake with buttercream frosting and a slice of cheesecake.

Mon., Nov. 12: Sassy S. eats 1 gingerbread cupcake with cream cheese frosting and 1 dark chocolate covered Macadamia nut.

Tues., Nov. 13: Sassy S. devours 5 Moonstruck Chocolate truffles.

Wed., Nov. 14: Sassy S. sits under the table at Bar 821 rocking back and forth, licking the frosting off a Williams Sonoma cupcake, caressing a giant chocolate egg wrapped in golden paper and wearing sour gummy rings on her fingers.

Thurs., Nov. 15: Sassy S. sucks on an invisible lollipop as she cries while watching "Grey's Anatomy" from her padded room at the Betty Crocker clinic for fatties who can't put the sugar down.

Damn you Miette, damn you and your freakishly adorable shop that looks like it just jumped off the pages of an Eloise book. Damn you and your pink stripy wallpaper. Damn you and your tubes of glistening jellybeans. Damn you and your GINGERBREAD!!!!! If the house in Hansel and Gretal was made of Miette's gingerbread there's no doubt in my mind that I'd try to eat those little bastard kids as well. Stay away from my gumdrops bitch!

-1 star because I got a creepy cupcake snob vibe from the sales lady. So the cupcakes with the marshmallow domes gross me out a little, so what? It looks like a boob. I wouldn't give my dad a boob cupcake on his birthday. Would you? Well, you're sick.
author: Sammy S.

description:
I always dreamed of being one of the lucky golden ticket holders that got to see the inside of Willy Wonka's Chocolate Factory. Yes, I am a chocoholic. And Miette comes close to being a chocoholic's paradise. Surrounded by sweets, I got an instant high. I wanted to go up to the wall and lick the colorful wallpaper. 

If it had not been for the hefty price tags, I probably would have said, "I'll have one of each." But I had to restrain myself and kept it down to 5. Along the counter, there were English and Nordic chocolate bars. I selected a Cadbury Flake and Bounty bar, because I had been missing them since my trip to the UK 2 years ago. 2 down, 3 to go.

Overwhelmed by all the different choices, I asked Caitlin, one of the owners who happened to be there, what her favorite chocolates were. She was truly exited to tell me about all of her favorites and even shared some of the chocolate bar that she had just opened up.  She told me about how she travels the world looking for different chocolates to bring back. Talk about a sweet job!

I picked out three of the ones she recommended:
- Melkesjokolade (for milk chocolate lovers, this is wonderfully creamy)
- Charles Chocolates Carmalized Crisped Rice in 41% Milk Chocolate (like Crunch bars? Well, this is WAY better)
- 3400 Phinney Bread & Dark Chocolate (with french bread mixed in, and it has sea salt which gives it a salty and bittersweet taste)

I'll be back soon, and will add to this growing list!

UPDATE 5/7/07:
You can also get cupcakes and macarons now!
author: Connie C.

description:
This place is like a candy mirage. You get all excited about an adorable little sweets shop and the idea of treating yourself, only to discover that Miette feels more like a museum than anything else. It feels so sterile, you don't want to touch anything and nothing really looks that tasty. The staff isn't friendly or inviting or helpful, which is too bad because Miette doesnt even let you scoop your own Jelly Bellies. I will concede that they do have some really unique candies, and a selection of licorice that'd be hard to find anywhere outside of Holland. Other than that, I found it disappointing. 

Conclusion: Go for the eye candy, not for your sweet tooth.
author: Alissa D.

description:
Cute alert!  Hide the children!

I don't have a sweet tooth.  I still couldn't help myself.  Jar after jar of colorful candies.  Local, organic, hand made.  Some from Europe, many Sicily.  Most have handwritten explanations.  Some rare and exotic.  They could turn into a your personal ever-present candy companion.  Others are just...candy.

The novelty bars are retro, few mass market brands.  This is NOT an Ike and Mike joint.  Yet old standards are here -- lemon drops and sours, gum balls, red hots, malted milk balls, Jordan almonds, chocolate pebbles.

Highlights are a strong line-up of Charles Chocolates, gooey buttery fresh homemade caramel, a licorice menu, and the famous cupcakes.

It's pricey, some jars are too high to reach or see properly, and they scoop things for you instead of letting you scoop for yourself.  It's an apothecary of candy more than a joyous candy explosion.  There's no minimum and they wrap things carefully in little bags with stickers and twine.

Right now I'm at a bar eating a cigar-shaped peach taffy log from New York so chewy and sticky my jaw is clicking like a $%*^#  and you know what?  It goes with the beer.  You heard it here.  CANDY GOES WITH BEER.
author: Gil S.

description: Went for the macaroons. Hazelnut was the best out of all the flavors that I got.  Picked up a bag of chocolate sable cookies just on a whim.  Chocolate with fleur de sel......need I say more.  The macaroons were good, but the cookies were the best.  Perfect with a cup of coffee.
author: Melissa Z.

description:
Not sure why there's "controversy" about a candy store! Miette is fantastic, and they are lovely to vegans.

I went in on their opening day, and I've been back about weekly since they opened. Not only do they have lots and lots of vegan candy, the staff there are consistently helpful and even excited to help me look for tasty things that fit my vegan diet. They've had no problem with going in the back room to read ingredients lists for their bulk items, even on busy days. They're even going as far to start adding a "vegan" tag in their inventory database so they can help find things more quickly.

The owners of the shop have put a lot of love into their new business, and it shows. They're friends with the Blue Bottle crew, who have always helped vegans enjoy a gourmet experience, and they've clearly passed this sensibility along to their friends at Miette.

Anyone who is "boycotting" Miette needs to go in and try it for themselves. Miette isn't a penny candy store - it's a gourmet candy shop, so if you don't like their prices, it's a fair criticism. To me, their attention to quality and detail is worth more than saving a dollar. But the idea that they're unfriendly to vegans doesn't match reality. Try it for yourself and enjoy.
author: Steve S.

description:
Sometimes I "forget" to review places that I go to a lot.  Sort of like I "forget" about the pack of grapefruit Mentos in my bag, or "forget" that I stashed a few Sea Salt Caramels in my car (for emergencies only, you understand).

Miette has got to be the prettiest candy store in the world, at least, in the USA.  Everything is displayed just so, coordinated by type or color, and in picture perfect glass jars that just beg you to reach inside and pull out a treat.  Somehow everything matches the pretty vintage wallpaper (oh, if only you could lick it, like in Willy Wonka!)  It's like a movie about a candy store, only you're not watching it, you're starring in it!  

Along with some hard-to-find European candies, Miette is a must if you are into licorice - they have oodles of different kinds, from the cute to the hard-core.  They have these tiny licorice marshmallows that are very unusual - I love them, but you have to be seriously into licorice to appreciate them.  

The locally made caramels are now a bit of a legend, and in demand.  They come in regular, burnt caramel, sea salt caramel, and bergamot - all are buttery, smooth, and melt-in-your-mouth-good.  It's hard to know what will be available on a given day, but they try to have at least one variety in stock at all times.  

I have always wondered who buys the enormous jawbreakers - if you have ever seen the movie "Jawbreaker", you will understand why I can no longer eat them - and I recently found out that it is the kids from the French-American school.  It's a total fad these days - who knew?

In addition to candy, the front case is filled with cakes and cupcakes, and my favorite guilty pleasure, macarons.  If you have never had a macaron from Miette, try one.  Even the most die-hard patisserie connoisseur would fall in love with these lovelies.

The staff has always been very helpful to me, offering tastes of new items or other candies in flavors that I like (a mix of grapefruit and plum Jelly Bellies - delicious).  They can also help you decide between the varieties of chocolate bars offered.

If you happen to run into me at Miette Confiserie, don't be alarmed if I act confused.  I am likely to "forget" how I got there, "forget" how $40 worth of candy got into my basket, and "forget" that I'm really supposed to be watching my sugar intake....
author: Liz S.

description:
Miette's reputation precedes them. Cupcakes...people say...you have to try the cupcakes.

Today I go down to pick up a partner from the lobby for a QBR and I see a pretty little pink bag. Oh a present.

a Miette present. My darling Account Manager brought us some treaties from SF. A little pink box of goodness to snack on during our meetings.

The pesky Lent thing was causing a problem, BUT hurrah the pink box also contained scones. Since scones are a breakfast food, not dessert...I was able to easily justify a taste or two of the small square scones. And thank the Lord she didn't bring cupcakes because I think I would have gotten seriously down and dirty with them and Lent bedarned.

Later in the day, someone forced me to try their little mini chocolate cream macaroon things. Well that's my story and I'm sticking to it anyway. I surely didn't grab it of my own free will. The chocolate cream macaroon thing was good. But not really Lent-breaking good, darnit.

Still gotta hold out the 5th star on account of no cupcake trying ... yet.
author: Mara T.

description:
This place makes me smile every time I walk up the steps through the door.  I love taking in the vision of the glass jars lined up on shelves filled with colorful candy.  

The people who work here are friendly and helpful, and are more than happy to give you descriptions/opinions of the various candy that they sell.  The only truly unfortunate part is that the candy is not cheap.  However, if you purchase loose candy in the smallest bag size, you have a tiny treat for a couple of dollars and perhaps even a candy out of the ordinary.  

My favorites here include the imported Italian Leone candies which are altoid-like in design, but come in several different flavors, the best being the vanilla.  Also tops are the Crunchie bar, gummy sour stars, chocolate sable cookies, house made graham crackers and the gummy grapefruit wedges.  

If you're craving some colorful fun, some tasty candy or if you're a fan of licorice, it's worth a trip!
author: Frances S.

description:
I knew this was going to be good. The same palates that devised the baked treats of the Ferry Building selected the most scrumptious candies this side of your Grandmother's kitchen.

This time-and-travel-warp has everything that candied dreams are made of. Beneath the high ceilings and rich mouldings resembling cake decorations is an array of tastes both comforting and exotic. I kept expecting to see Oompaloompas popping up.

From my favorite Nougats du Provence to Pixy-Stix, from Charles' Chocolate to Cadbury Curlywurly, from Jelly Belly to a chunky choco-bar called, "YORKIE - It's not for girls!" Within minutes, wife's sweet tooth sent that ad tagline straight to hell. 

Ironic, because this place is candy heaven.
author: Andy R.

description:
The Child Beauty Pageant Queen of candy stores.  Cute--but just a little too cute.  Well coiffed--but just a little too well coiffed.  Precious--yeah, you get the picture.

I'm sorry, but for the prices, and the lavish attention to setting, the sweets here would be laughed out of any self respecting small European town.   

And the service is delivered with that icky "you don't really belong here dear, but we're going to be nice to you" kind of smile.  Like a painted on pageant rictus.

The cupcakes, for starters have been stale every time I've sampled one.  And I don't mean a little long in the tooth from this morning, I mean stale in the "this shouldn't be sold at full price" kind of stale.  And stingy portioned, at that.

The sweets are packaged and merchandised prettily but let's face it, you can get this or better at many other places at comparable or even more reasonable prices.  

Like any pre-teen beauty queen, the styling here disguises the fact that there is a slightly bratty kid underneath all the cuteness with some serious work to do to live up to the spackle and paint.

I hovered over the two-star icon above when making this review, and I guess the third star comes from the fact that some of the sweets, like the varied licorices, are pretty good, despite the hefty price tag.  It could be worse, it could be one of the old liquor stores that dotted the hood in its benighted era.  That is the only reason there are three stars at the top of this review, and not two.

Flame away, Jon Benet.
author: Kevin S.

description:
One trip up to San Francisco = 2 trips to Miette (1 on Hayes St and 1 at the Famer's Market in the Ferry Bulding)!! Although I tried my first macaron at Paulette's, I bought my first one here. 

The Hazelnut was definitely my favorite!!! The vanilla was disappointing and the chocalate was just okay. I also really like the grapefruit macaron!
author: Stephen N.

description: Didn't realize there was a Miette branch by the playground in Hayes Valley.  Like the little goodies there ... but my favorite is still the ginger snap cookies.  $8 is a bit pricey but for how it tastes, definitely worth it.
author: F. P.

description:
If Miette C. were a Yelp profile I would PM, fan, UFC, Cute Pic, Current Crush her so hard her cries of "Stalker!" would immediately lead to my User Profile Removed. 

In the mean time, I will be content to bask in all of her adorable, glistening, precious pink glory, munching on a Vosges' Mo's Bacon Bar or 2, 3, 4... as I wait.  Patiently.

Minus one star for the mark-ups.
author: Natasha S.

description:
Adorable small shop in the heart of Hayes Valley with a wide variety of treats to soothe your sweet tooth. The fleur de sel caramels were quite possibly the best candy I've ever tried. The gingerbread and carrot cake cupcakes with cream cheese icing were also delicious. 

Bonus points for the little park outside where you can enjoy your treats sitting in the sun.
author: Emily C.

description:
An adorable candy store - small, pink and sweet! 
Find your favorite flavored jelly beans, miette cookies, or miette cupcakes. Had a bite of the PISTACHIO MACAROON and it's delicious ($1.50 each). The grapefruit flavor wasn't too great. It's cream filling was sour tasting...gotta have me some more macaroons.
author: Oanh N.

description: Prettiest candy shop in town. Their Sea Salt Caramel is to die for!
author: Pooky C.

description: My friend bought me some Miette gingersnaps for my birthday, and they are frken amazing!!! I'm convinced to come here and try something else, but for now, they get my vote! Oh, and it crosses another one off the list of 7x7 must tries. Two birds, one stone!
author: Camille T.

description:
SUPER CUTE. 

I took my cousin out to lunch for her birthday and as bday girl privilege we needed some sort of sweet sugary goodness. We were in the neighborhood and she was the one who took me to Miette.

YAYs!! : this shop is so sweet in every sense. From the tall candy filled jars behind the counter to the sweetly decorated counter top tables. When I  first walked in, my spirits instantly lifted! I gushed like a child wanting EVERYTHING in the store. The cupcakes looked so perfect, I was afraid to touch. 

MEHs:  This could just be me, but the sweets were a little too pricey for me. I guess what I'm really referring to is what I purchased. This is somewhat of a mute argument because I did end up spending some $$ there.  I couldn't resist because what I did get I don't think I could have gotten else where.

PURCHASES: I bought 3 chocolate mustaches on a stick!!! It was pretty funny because my girlfriends and I have an on-going joke about drawing mustaches on our fingers and going out to the bars. It's a long story... but I'm sure you get why I had to get them.

Overall: "Yay!! I'm a fan!!"
author: Dorothea G.

description:
Having lived in the area for a brief time I was surprised I never had visited this place before.
As somewhat of a shortbread junkie, I took to heart the lavender shortbread, along with my tongue, stomach, and wallet they all felt it, not in that order mind you. Keeping up that trend, I got some chocolate lavender macaroons, what a flavor, not super sweet like most you would find. And lavender. Such an underutilized spice. Bravo. Bravo.
author: D. R.

description:
I do I do I do
of course I will marry you, but u cant tell my husband. When I walked into Miette I wanted to get down on one knee and propose. I had only been there once, but i knew it was love at first sight. I wanted to go wild. rip everything off the counters ,put it in my mouth and than grawllllll.
Unfortunately, I couldnt because someone might get scared and call the cops. 
plus im sure they have a policy about paying before eating.

Anyway,  I love this store. The women in here are absoulutely sweet just like the candy they sale. They took time to answer my questions even if it was just about candy or their yummy yummmy yummmy cupcakes.
I will definately be back .
author: LaNiesha P.

description:
Until I move to Finland where the people like their licorice salty (or where the people, like their licorice, are salty), I will be buying my black licorice at Miette. 

Miette imports the majority of its 18 varieties of black licorice from Denmark, actually, but regardless you can get your flavor mix of salty, sweet and anise-spiced licorice; your soft, chewy, firm and in-between textured licorice; and your cube, gumdrop and cat-shaped licorice here.

My favorites are the slightly sweet, stick-shaped Heksehyl Zoete and the Drop Haringen which are dusted with salt and shaped like fish. 

Consult the "Miette Black Licorice Menu" (resting on a shelf near you) for a full list with taste/texture descriptions and, if still undecided, grab one of the staff for guidance. The girl who helped me on my intial shop visit patiently indulged my request for 3-4 pieces each of 10 varieties and this required she make use of the ladder several times. Of course if she were from Finland (thus taller) she wouldn't have needed the ladder and I would have paid for my goods and gotten out of the store a lot quicker. But as I did not mind the additional time spent loitering here I will not withhold another star.

The licorice, like most of the store's candy, is beautifully displayed in heavy-lidded, sculpted glass jars and arranged atop cabinetry and tiered shelving. 

A center table showcases the premium chocolate candy bars (one bar was described thus: "It's like a Reeses peanut butter cup but ten times better"; the description held) and all along the front of the service counter you'll find the retro packaged candies and bars. The back wall selection includes the gummy and sour candies. And the gumballs. I'm not a fan but bought a few anyway because I couldn't resist their distinctive colors combined with that smooth roundness. I'd be happy to keep them on display in a jar on a shelf in my own apartment . Ditto the pastel green, pink and yellow color-coated maltballs.

Some reviewers refer to the store's "whimsy". While glances about the interior will reveal color and beauty, and produce definite smiles, the feel of the store is more fancy, less fanciful; less whimsical, more refined. 

That's not Gene Wilder spinning madly at the cotton candy machine. And that's definitely not Johnny Depp eliminating the kid who just dipped his nose-pickin' hand into the $100/lb candied rose petals. 

No, I think this is Cate Blanchett's store. And that's cool; I like Cate.
author: Michelle M.

description:
This is a place of childhood dreams and adult palates. It fills me with excitement and wonder and turns innocent passersby into a candy converts. 

Tonight we stopped for some candy coated almonds, but no visit is complete without a licorice tasting or two (visit Michelle M.'s review for the lowdown on the many varieties) The store clerks are so friendly, welcoming, and encouraging. No amount of tasting is too much. Tonight our candy host mentioned tastings available in the chocolate drawer. Who doesn't love a chocolate drawer? I tried not to leap for the skies and am holding my abounding enthusiasm until my next visit. 

After buying some almonds, licorice and a cookie, we stopped to greet Henry the candy store canine. He was sweet too and was as welcoming as his human counterparts. 

I am drawn to places that are well designed and pleasing to the eye. This is such a place. It is cute without being syrupy and sleek with out being sterile. It is a high class candy joint that doesn't miss a beat. They  even offer up Pop Rocks for those days you want to revisit the late 1970's.
author: Tina E.

description:
Attention people with "warped tongues", a.k.a. .... people who like licorice.  I have a so called "warped tongue" , according to some people in these parts.

You will find no less than about 10 different kinds of BLACK licorice here.  Yup ... TEN at least!

You want a licorice flavored marshmallow?  Got it.  Want it salted?  Yup.  Maybe mint licorice is your passion?  Got that too.  Discs or gumdrop shape?  You betcha.  Chewy or hard?  I had no idea there were so many choices!

So Lainie and I enter the store, and I made a bee line for the glass jars filled with black licorice-y goodness.  While she was into other things, I got to sample many different kinds, with the assistance of the very helpful staff.  They have just about every kind of Jelly Belly ... but for some reason NO BLACK JELLY BELLY??!!  That's OK ... I have my fill of better licorice!  Possibly the best combination of Jelly Belly's are the Sizzling Cinnamon and Black Licorice.  Those two combine for a powerful, spicy, licorice kick.

Also they have many different kinds of "Old Tyme" chocolate bars.  Cravers of Violet Crumble will cure their cravings here.  They also have many different kinds or organic chocolate bars, malt balls ...(I got a combo of Milk and Dark Chocolate!)  Since it's Miette, they have those really good bite size cookies.

This is a revitalized area, and totally different from the last time I was in the neighborhood, before they tore down the freeway.  I saw many places I want to try.  But will have to save it for another day.  Since I travel exclusively by BMW ... (BART, MUNI, walk), I get to peer into many places, read the menus.  You can't do that with a car, can you?!  See, walking has it's perks!

Many thanks to Lainie L for buying the licorice!  I know it's against everything she believes in, and for prolly making her car stink of the stuff!

And for those that quote or refer to the "Candy Man" song, you do know that that song is about, right??  Not the sugar candy!  "Lucy in the Sky with Diamonds" rings a bell.
author: Michael M.

description:
I love most all things vintage, kitschy, french inspired, & retro. No really. I collect owls, mushrooms, 1960's dolls with big heads, giant eyes, skinny legs,... you get the point. My girlfriends have been telling me how much I would love Miette for the past several years, yet I never made it out to one of their locations until yesterday. 

I caught the Miette bug when my BFF decided to get my bachelorette party favor bags here. Adorbs. They supply the cellophane bags and super cute pastel Miette stickers, you choose what retro reproduction candies you want to stick in, anything from black jack gum, french dark chocolates, to bubble gum cigarettes and marshmallow sticks. A perfect accompaniment for my vintage themed wedding!

So when this same best friend turned 30 this last weekend, I wasted no time in calling up Miette to order the perfect birthday cake. I chose a large lemon debutante (3 layers of vanilla sponge cake, homemade lemon curd, and very light lemon buttercream) and it was a HUGE hit. I am attaching a photo for it really was the sweetest looking and amazingly tasty cake and my friend was super excited about it as were her guests. 
But aside from the delightful cake, the store is surprisingly even better, a soft pastel paradise filled to the brim with vintage candy jars containing all sorts of wonder brightly colored old fashioned candies. They also have a plentiful selection of French macarons and cupcakes. 
I couldn't get out of there without picking out a tiny assortment of goodies to munch on my way to my friends then on the drive back to the east bay after the party, so I picked up the following: a bag filled with milk chocolate rocks (they really look like rocks!), a couple squares of recommended Dauphin dark chocolate in 70% cacao and earl grey, 2 chocolate toad stool mushrooms, and a bag of 6 homemade vanilla marshmallows. I have never in my life enjoyed such delicious marshmallows, these little wonders are filled with tiny specks of real vanilla bean and will leave a giant smile on your face. My husband popped one of them in his vanilla latte and said it was delicious! I bet.

In addition to the goods, the staff are super professional and knowledgeable and they informed me that they will be getting in a bunch more mushroom themed items for the holiday. Hooray! I can't wait to return... :)
author: Callie K.

description:
Mmmmm...I must have done something right in life to deserve stumbling upon this candy heaven from the moment I stepped foot into this sweet, sweet shop. 

If there is ever such a thing as candy heaven , this is how I would imagine it to be. Down to the pink decor and the adorable candy girl working behind the counter (lucky girl). Its all a perfect setting to satisfy your sweet tooth!

Wait..it gets better!

There's more than just candies here. They sell my ultimate weakness. Kryptonite to my belly...

MACAROONS!
 I LOVE LOVE LOVE Macaroons! This beautiful (but evil) shop sells an assortment of these dainty but OH SO tasty cookies. I chose three Hazelnut macaroons and CHOWED down all em' before I even got back to the car. All that was left of my insatiable appetite for these sweets were the little tasty crumbs sprinkled around my mouth..

What I really enjoyed about being here is not only because of the candies, or the extra pleasant service and attention that I received as I OGLED each and every sweet on display, but it was the memories that it evoked in me. Miette Confiserie brought me back to my stay in Paris. I had the greatest time there and my fondest memory is walking through the streets of Paris eating chocolate and hazelnut macaroons...and yes,  still with the tasty little crumbs sprinkled around my mouth.
author: First C.

description:
I LOVE MIETTE. I think I will name my first born child Miette. What do you think of that? hmmmm.

For all you gluten free people out there their little melt in your mouth cookies up front are all gluten free. So enjoy will you? 

Their cupcakes are delicious, and at $3 a pop it is no more expensive than Starbucks.

The store is so dang cute that it makes me want to be a child again, begging my mother for bubble gum sticks and peppermint patties. YUM!
author: Chelsea G.

description:
Hopped into this cute old fashioned french candy shop a few days ago.  It made me reminiscent of the days of yore when people used to go into candy shops and buy yummy goodies like frogs or gumdrops or cookies.  While I wasn't around during those days, I can imagine people going into Woolworth's and picking out a chocolate bon bon for a nickel.

This place is a lot fancier than Woolworth's.  It has an array of original gourmet confections like candy and cookies and even cake!  There was a beautiful sparkly princess cake that looked like a snowball.  It would be perfect for my bday, as I am a princess.

For the holidays, I noticed some very cute partridge and pear cookies, a giant Christmas tree, as well as chocolate letters that spelled BRRR.

Every item here is individual and inspired.  You can tell a lot of creativity goes into the goods, which is why it is cool to browse.  It's almost like a museum de candy.  The decor is a gumdrop tree made of real gumdrops!  They had a Vosges chocolate bar with bacon as well as a lollipop that was inspired by said bar.

They also had a selection of macarons.  I tried the lemon one which had a lovely creamy filling and sweet outside.  I probably couldn't eat many of them, but they do look terribly cute!

It's great to browse around here and ogle at the wonderful sweets and treats.
author: apple r.

description: Were it not for you, Miette Confiserie, I'd never have known the simple joy that is PINK GRAPEFRUIT MENTOS.
author: Miriam W.

description:
In my opinion, the cupcakes are too dry, as are the macarons.  And the ginger snaps?  I'm not a fan.  

I want this to be 2.5 stars because Miette isn't really that bad - it's just a personal preference.
author: Melinda C.

description:
Being in Miette is the embodiment of "kid in a candy store" for me. The decor is right out of a vintage children's story book and the sweets range from Pop Rocks and Jelly Bellys to Vosge's Haut Couture chocolate and imported European candies.

They also have a delicious selection of baked goods. My favorite is the Old Fashion Cupcake because the boiled icing is divine. Light and fluffy, it's the perfect pairing with the moist chocolate cake. (Buttercreams can be a bit too rich for me.)

My only complaint is the inconsistency of their stock. I've been waiting for them to get more candy coated anise seeds. Apparently there's a hiccup with their distributor. And recently, I purchased a small box of sugar-free fruity hard candies from Switzerland (?) but when I went back again, they were no where to be found. What a tease!

Well, I do have another complaint, but it's more of a request. I would like more fruit flavored/inspired candies. Nougat and chocolate is nice but yawn.

Regardless, this place is still high on my guilty pleasures list. If not just because of the Old Fashion Cupcakes. Someone buy me a baker's dozen, please!

PS Wheel-chair accessibility is located around the corner on Linden Street.
author: Viv C.

description: I'm not AT ALL a girly-girl, but this place is just incredibly cute and adorable that it makes me feel like the little girly-girl i never was (Lol). Its a tad on the expensive side but the presentation is awesome. They have a great selection of sweets from hard candies, to cookies, to macaroons, to ice cream sandwiches. The macaroons and ice cream sandwiches are scrumptious. I always try to stop by this shop whenever I go on a mini vaca to SF.
author: Celine P.

description:
Charming!

I didn't realize we had a new candy store in the neighborhood, what a nice surprise to stumble across this *sweet* candy store while walking around on a beautiful day.

Their treats for sale are fun, quirky and eclectic... I was also impressed with the friendly sales folks, they were knowledgeable and clearly have a passion for fine candy. 

I think we will get along VERY WELL. :)

Welcome to the neighborhood, I'm looking forward to my next visit already!
author: Nenette Y.

description:
1. It's clean. Sparkling Clean.  Like Mr. Clean CLEAN. All polished and scrubbed like she's dressed to go the Prom.  You can probably lick the floor.  And that is WAY out of character for me to say b/c I'm the biggest germophobe on the planet.  Hand sanitizer anyone?

2. Their MACARONS!!! I'm now obsessed.  I'm on a mission to try every flavah.  I had vanilla and I'm sooooo NOT vanilla.  But it was deee-lish! 
My friend said the gardenia one was like eating flowers.  Her bf asked, "Then why would you buy a macaron when you can stuff an actual flower in your mouth and get the same taste?"  HA. 
If heaven can come into two scrumptious pieces with cream in between, then I want to go there PRONTO b/c it's eternal, right?  That means I can eat Miette macarons forever?  "Forevah evah???  Forevah evah..."  

3. It's purrrrty inside.  Every kid's fantasy.  The best was seeing a little girl wearing a tutu outfit stopping by on her way to ballet class.  She probably burned off the candy by doing some demi-pliés and junk later on. Hopefully, she won't think about burning calories at age 4 b/c we all know ballerinas have some serious eating issues, if you know what I mean...
author: S K.

description:
OVERALL
Crack'n Good Grommet!

BLACK LICK
Great selection of black licorice!  They are happy to help you sample them tasty nugs.  There are a few types that combine the salty action... the mild is what I got which is really tasty.

CHOCOLATE
They have some bar made from the smallest percent of the top cocoa beans you can find... and the bar is slamm'n.  You'll see a little sign next to the chocolate talking about it... just get the dame thing and eat the hell out of it.  OMFG!

TOFFEE
At first, I was amazed at how perfect these suckers looked.  After one bite, I thought perhaps the flavor was a bit odd... and much munching later, I realized that I just had to get to know this toffee.  It's top notch.

CUPCAKES
I didn't know they had them!  Genevieve Y. let me know that if one actually looks past the counter, yee will find glory.  Thanks G!  I must go back and try them.  

ODDS AND ENDS
All kinds of yummy bits laying around, like caramel chews and old style favs.

LOCATION
Love that this is by the little park.  Precious.
author: Dan M.

description:
With this adorable addition to the 'hood, the 3-block radius encompassing Franklin and Laguna and Page and Grove is getting more and more dangerous for the female population. Trendy clothes and accessories? Check. Hip brunch spots? Check. Mouth-watering cakes and cookies? Check. Ridiculously overpriced baby gift ideas? Check. Hormones-inducing yet classy cocktail lounges? Check. And now with Miette, it's impossible for a girl to behave herself.

Damn, the Willy Wonka and Parisian references already taken. Ok, this new candy store is packed with so much fluff it looks like it came straight out of Main Street, Disneyland. If you're allergic to the color pink, do not go in there. I stopped by after hour #3 on opening day. There's so much sugar in the place I felt like my teeth were already starting to rot. But having been slapped with a $300 bill from the dentist recently I restrained myself from picking up every kind of candy there was. I couldn't help myself though, when I spotted my favorite chocolate, Tranquility (lavender milk chocolate) from NewTree, and thank god Miette carries the 3-pieces pack instead of the full bar. I also picked up a pack of Austrian hazelnut wafers and a piece of fig chocolate.

Now, since it was opening day, none of the candies had any descriptions or price tags. There were also no plastic bags or containers to hold your selections. And since there were no price tags, it took the sales clerk a while to find my items in the computer to ring me up. Hopefully these kinks will be smoothed out soon so us salivating sugar fiends can have a field day here. Gentlemen-you will make out like a winner here shopping for all the females in your life.
author: Linda L.

description:
The key to having the best Valentine's Day ever includes a trip to Miette! The shop gals are helpful and super friendly, even waving and greeting little kids walking by the shop. My boyfriend, who did not want to come as he is a complete poo-head, couldn't resist purchasing candy cigarettes and a packet of honey drops he hadn't had since he was a kid. As for me, I came for the peach penguins and a box of macarons (you haven't lived until you've had a fresh macaron...) 

This is definitely the place to be after a long work day or if you're in need of a gift for a friend.

ETA: I dropped by today to pick up an all pink baggie of candy for my BFF's birthday and the counter gals were awesome. They pointed out all the pink candy and even a few that they hadn't put out yet. AND they are carrying Vosges' new candy delight...a flying chocolate bacon pig. They also had maple and bacon lollipops. Seems like every time I visit, Miette has brand new inventory!

ETA2: My newest obsession are their caramels! I brought a packet with me when I flew to Rome and now one of my favorite memories is sitting at a table, basked in sunlight and eating a bergamot caramel.
author: Nathalie L.

description:
Love the design.  Beautiful interior. . .even the candy jars add to the great design.

They do have some rare candy choices but I wasn't that impressed, like I wasn't drooling and my heart didn't race or anything about the selection.  They do have an mpressive selection of salty drop black licorice (leker!), matter of fact, it's the best I've seen outside of Holland.    

I'll stop by whenever I'm in the area because I love the design, and I love black licorice.  

Pretty pretty Miette Confiserie.
author: James M.

description:
The cupcakes are okay here- good frosting.  Personally, I love Tom's cookies devils' food cupcake better.  (3 stars)

1/2 star extra for having CHOCOLATE MUSTACHES (SOOOOOOOO COOL!!!)

1/2 star extra for being the cutest store ever!!!!!  :)
author: F K.

description:
The macaroons are heavenly. Absolutely heavenly. And they typically come in delicious flavors, like rose and strawberry and hazelnut. 
They make lavender shortbreads that are also delicious.
Otherwise, their candies can be expensive. But if you need something that's hard to come by, I'm sure they'd have it. It's expensive for a reason. 
And their macaroons are delicious.
The people that work there are sweet and patient when you can't quite decide how many and which macaroons to get. 
The store itself is very cute inside!
author: April L.

description:
Probably one of the cutest shops ever. Well, cutest CANDY shop.
The treats are delicious. I picked up a few chocolate yummies and a couple non-chocolate treats that are equally enjoyed by my pals.
I really enjoyed the taffy. And the caramel. Oh, and the licorice. AND pretty much everything with sugar in it. And everything lemon flavored.

Needless to say, I really like this store. 
The treats are delicious, although they are not cheap.
author: Syd V.

description:
This review is just for the Ice Cream Sandwich ($4).

My b/f and I brought a strawberry ice cream sandwich with chocolate wafer cookies.The chocolate cookies were thin and crispy, which paired nicely with the ice cream. I actually prefer the crispy cookie over chewy/softer cookies for an ice cream sandwich. The ice cream had a strong strawberry profile and it was tart compared to other strawberry ice creams. What I didn't like was the texture of the ice cream: it was icy -- not creamy at all.

Verdict:

I would not buy this item again.
author: S. H.

description:
You either love or you hate black licorice.  I walked into Miette Confiserie for the first time as a loather of the stuff.  My curiosity got the best of me though when I spied the full wall of imported licorice, ranging in taste and texture from sweet, soft, chewy molasses to the jaw-breaking ammonia laced salty stuff.  Like the sweetest stealer of innocence, Caitlin gently led me through the gamut of flavors and textures, starting me off slowly by sampling the milder pieces and building up to the ones that most would consider an acquired taste.  Needless to say, this former licorice hater is now a sugar addled fiend who devours half a pound a week.  The other day I caught myself making the snobbish declaration through a mouthful of sticky black gumdrops, "There's no such thing as red licorice!"  It's embarrassing, really.  

Apart from the licorice wonderland, I was blown away by Caitlin's extensive knowledge of the taste and origin of every piece of candy the store carries, and genuine passion for what they sell, the care with which they package it, and the time they're willing to spend with their customers, even on busy days.  Worth every penny!
author: Christina K.

description:
I have been supporting Miette since they opened. They have there usual pastries and they have some unusual candy.

The space is cute. It feels like a store, not a cafe. It is hard to be both in this town and I think they are making the correct design choices.

The macaroons are my favorite in the United States. I have not had better. If I serve them at a party or to friends, I am always flattered with praise for providing them. Cupcakes are the other pastry that I love there.

They also have a great candy collection. I have a new favorite. I bought them here, they are chocolate rocks, meaning they look like rocks, but they are really chocolates. They make a nice addition to a dessert plate or as decorative edibles. 

Give Miette a chance if you haven't tried them. This location is much bigger than the Ferry Building with a bigger selection. Also, cute shops and a park across the street if you want to enjoy your sweets as soon as possible....
author: Christopher W.

description:
Dear Childhood,

I am so glad I have found you! Stay secure and warm in this candy heaven. 

Love, 
E

buttery caramels, scharffenberger chocolate cake, and a gummy selection perfect for your needs... all pleasantly located in front of a puppy-friendly park.
author: Coco E.

description:
I dropped in at Miette for the first time today & fell in love! It's an candyland for adults, with perfect caramels, cupcakes, chocolate bars, macarons and more. 

Grab a cup of coffee from Blue Bottle down the street, a handful of candy or a delightful gingerbread with cream cheese frosting cupcake and sit out in the Hayes Valley Park watching families walk together, pigeons peck, and dogs play. 

Guaranteed to make your day sweeter.
author: Sharand N.

description: I was very disapointed with this place mainly because of the service. I asked for a bag of candy for $4 and she rings it up for $5 I ask why and she says because she doesnt know the price until she rings it up.. So apparently if it is over $4 she cant just take out a few candies???? And then I get home eager to eat the bubblegum she said she put in and I find out they are MALTS which I strongly dislike. So overall dissapointed.
author: Sophia C.

description:
Personally, I'm not a big sugar person, but...

If you're a candy and/or sugar fan, it's cute.  A little sterile actually, but a nice mix of artisanal old-school and modern gourmet treats.

I didn't see any candies that they made themselves when I was there actually.  Maybe they're behind the counter?  Or, maybe they're just getting ramped up.  I saw they're going to be making some Rose Geranium Organic Cotton Candy soon....  I think I'd be into that.
author: Melanie C.

description:
I went in last night for the first time, and stuck up a conversation with one of the owners.  She was funny, friendly, and gave free samples, so who's to complain?  

The prices are completely in line with the products.  The gumballs are cheap - the black cherry was a little explosion of flavor, as was the peach, but the strawberry shortcake blew the top of my head off, so potently good was the flavor.

I bought a $10 Rococo chocolate bar with 65% cacao, flavored with Basil and Persian Lime.  Wow, what  an incredible bar - the flavors change as you eat the bar, but it's really good.  Not the best $10 chocolate bar I've ever had, but delicious.

I really enjoyed myself, and will definitely be back.
author: Paul B.

description:
Think Willy Wonka for the retro-cool Hayes Valley crowd. If I liked Jelly Beans, Pastilles, and Cotton Candy I would give it a five, but I don't. Others do, so check it out! Great chocolate selection also (I spent $40 bucks on a tin of chocolate covered almonds, a tin of chocolate covered Hazelnuts, and three chocolate bars: one with ginger, one with Coffee Beans, and one with Coconut Curry!!!). More money than brunch for two at Citizen Cake!!!
I still prefer Scharfenberger, but Miette is undeniably cute. Your girlfriend or mom will love it
author: Johnny O.

description:
Miette is a dream !!
Yes the candy and treats are a little pricey ... but that's because they are made with quality ingredients  . If you are looking for starburst or snickers you are in the wrong place. I had a chocolate cupcake with meringue frosting tonight and it was super.. I loooove the Fluer-de-sel caramels too such heavenly buttery goodness  :)
author: lizabeth j.

description:
such a girlie shop...
i will be taking my two nieces simone and zoe here soon!
the candies, cookies, chocolates, all very nice.
but come here for the TO DIE FOR macaroons.
OMG, one bite and you are hooked for life.
vanilla, chocolate, strawberry you cannot go wrong with any of them.
personal choice is the vanilla.
wow!
author: Jeff W.

description:
This place is cute, well thought out and a fun place to bring friends/family looking for something unique, but I was a little dismayed by the business practices.

I visited the candy store on Octavia and purchased a few items, the store was clean, the staff attentive and I was happy when I left.

Continuing my touring of the city, I ended up at the Ferry Building and noticed a 2nd Miette with a larger bakery selection, so I went in to peak at the selection and noticed the candy I had purchased was $1.50 cheaper here. 

I inquired why what I purchased was $4 in one store and $2.50 in the other and the cashier gave me a blow off answer. I showed her my receipt and she proceeded to tell me there was only a $.50 difference, even though the price card clearly showed they were selling for $2.50.

She offered to refund me the $.50 difference which I thought was kind of her as I hadn't purchased them in her store, but why lie about the price when it is clearly marked on the little sign? I didn't want to create any more of scene than I had, so I left with my $.50. 

If you are going to inflate your prices, at least have them be uniform throughout all the stores. It makes the business look bad and as a customer, I would think twice before returning.
author: Heidi S.

description:
Love this place.  
So darn appealing.
Feel as if I have stepped back in time or I'm in a fairy tale.
Slightly salty licorice kitties rock.
Have gotten a little too hooked on the kitties.
You only live once.
Je t'adore, Miette.
author: Sandy G.

description:
I was like a kid in a candy store!! They have the most beautiful pieces of candy imported from Italy, UK, France... even some oldies but goodies, like Sugar Daddys...mmmm 

Everyone is incredibly helpful.. I somehow managed to spend $35 dollars.. Some pieces are a little expensive.. but when you bite into every single piece, it's a little piece of heaven.
author: Monica S.

description:
Fanciful & beautiful French eclectic decor resonates at their Hayes Valley store.  Bigger of the two, it features more of their baked goods & sinfully yummy candy.  

Happily visited their Ferry Building shop.  Broke down & bought a small package of peanut butter cookies.  Worth the $5.  A moment on the lips is totally worth a lifetime on the hips.
author: Jen L.

description:
Yet another super cute little bakery. What is particuarly awesome about this is that they do adult birthday parties complete with champagne and cotton condy. How fun and different is that? 

Anyway, this is like your childhood fantasies come true, but with an obviously more adult and rather "sophisticated" twist in terms of taste. I'll be honest, I think there are probably better baked goods to be had, but I am one of those people who can't resist "cute" and so they get an extra star. When you're visual, presentation is a plus! 

Even if you're not in to sweets, check this out just for kicks.
author: Anita B.

description:
I love everything about this store; the soft light, the lack of clutter and airiness of the layout, simplicity, yet very high quality. As they present their store, so too is their food. Miette sells a plethora of high quality, largely-European chocolate, delicious baked goods, and other assorted sweets. Granted some of their filling-out-the-store stock is less impressive, but who is really coming to a place like this with the intention of buying generic sweets? 

Miette most notably serves truly exceptional macarons. If you are at all in doubt, try Miette's macarons side by side with those from La Boulange, a whole 100 feet down Octavia. If you want an independent opinion, give the same taste test to the homeless guy who always sits on Hayes st at the end of Octavia with his little fishing pole and cup. I've found he's quite amenable to a taste test, and he always agrees with everything I say if it means he'll get more food. 

Until the Parisian chain Laduree opens its first US store in NYC (scheduled for Oct. 2008), Miette is the place to be for macarons.
author: Frank B.

description:
I love this place. I always walked passed it but it was always closed. Finally I got the chance to check it out and I loved it. I love their chocolates and their cupcakes. 
the cupcakes are worth it. 
Very cute for presents as well. Nice chocolate gift boxes.
author: Berenice D.

description: I've been waiting to come to this Miette for the longest time, and opportunity came knocking this past weekend because we had time to kill before dinner.  It is super cute in here with tons of different sweets all displayed in such a cute manner.  I stocked up on some cute chocolates.. one was a big initial K, and some cute holiday ones as well, and a bunch of yummy macarons.... I wanted to get a cake as well but will wait to come back to get one :)  Everyone was nice and friendly and welcoming.
author: Kymberli C.

description:
OK this is out of a kids book!!  what an amazing place.  Love the creativity of the selection of goodies and the willingness everyone has there to make you as happy as you can be.
This is my kids favorite place to go for dessert after a nice meal at Bar Jules (I need to review next!!!)
Thanks for helping make the city so sweek!
author: Emi C.

description:
I guess if there's something to get here, it's those caramels. They've been salted with the sweat of Oakland schoolkids. Very much tastes like pond water in the mouth, but in rather a nice way.

Most of the bulk candy doesn't really seem like it's for buying. There are no bags, tongs, scoops. I suppose you ask one of those ponies that runs the place, but who knows how to talk to a pony? Not me.
author: Tim S.

description: Expensive, but this place is so, so cute! It's gorgeous inside and the treats are even packaged fancy. It's beautiful and I'd love to spend all day in here eating random treats. Too bad I can't afford it.
author: christine c.

description:
walk in and all of a sudden i feel like a little girl wearing my poofy fru fru pink dress, some of my mom's earrings staring and drooling over the wide variety of sweets from all over the world and the toy-looking delicious cupcakes and cakes. 

the cupcakes are delicious. creamy frosting, not too sweet. super moist cake with a sonic boom of yum. friendly staff too.

thumbs up: decor, variety of candies, chocolates, cupcakes
thumbs down: gets busy, and the red dot on the famous old fashioned cupcake is a peanut! i had no clue. its dangerous because i ate it and i'm allergic! had to spit that piece out, but the rest of the cupcake was oh so good.
author: Lauren Y.

description:
Between Miette Confiserie and Christopher Elbow, Hayes Valley has two top-notch candy stores. While Christopher Elbow resembles either a jewelry store or a chic lounge, Miette Confiserie looks like a candy store is supposed to look, or more to the point, how a child thinks a candy store should look.

The disconnect here is that most children can't afford $3.50 chocolate bars or cupcakes. And the much-younger version of me would have balked at the sophisticated flavors at play in many of these candies. Heck, I can't decide if the chocolate bacon bar would ruin me by tasting awful or would ruin me by tasting fantastic...

Anyways, the store is cute and pricey. I liked my cupcake, but the ones at Sweet Things bakery in the Cal-Mart on California are still a better value. I liked their selection of European candies, but I was disappointed that they didn't have that hazelnut candybar that I bought every time I saw it in London several years ago. If I remembered the name, I would have asked them to stock it. You'll just have to trust me on this one. You can also trust me that the candy and the staff here are top-notch. Just know that you'll pay accordingly.
author: Timothy O.

description:
This store is a dentist's worst nightmare. Everything is presented so beautifully, that you can't help but want to try everything. I mean, if it's in a pretty glass jar it can't rot your teeth, right? The chocolate selection is good too; you're sure to find varieties you've never seen before but will undoubtedly want to try. Oh, and if you want to ingratiate yourself to your parents around the holidays, simply utter the words, "I'm headed down to Miette Confiserie to see if I can find some last-minute gifts."

Did I mention they make cotton candy? No? Well they do. They make it to order. Mmmmmm...
author: Katie I.

description: This is such a cute candy store! I love it. The workers are really nice! I love taffy, they had peach taffy, my favorite fruit and my favorite type of candy. I like.
author: Janet Z.

description: A very nice children and adult confectionery shop with sweet baked goods. There were many candies I've never seen before and had very high quality chocolate bars, as well as walls of candies in large glass jars. Small selection of macarons, but a nice varieties of cup cakes.
author: Wolfy W.

description:
So where did all those liquor stores in hayes valley go? Its like one day, somone decided to tear down some freeway and the next day, my easily accessible and every so economically priced St. Ides was nowhere to be found- but on the flipside, I can now get super tasty (and i'm sure completely non-fattening) cupcakes and candies in a place that must be straight out of alice in wonderland (minus the Acid and that whole Jawberwocky thing).

Miette is pretty freaking awesome- everything is beatifully displayed from there chocolates to their hard candies and of course, the super-sized pixie sticks (new addiction). Damn, just breathing in here got me a sugar rush! Beyond that though, the prices weren't too insane (but more than a pack of sweet tarts). MMmm...those cinnamon disks are crazy good.... 

Long story short- miette= enough sugar to make Veruca Salt smile :)
author: Tim V.

description:
I stopped here after raiding Paulette.  The store is freakin' adorable!  Kinda like what I wished my bedroom looked like when I was 6.  They have all sorts of unique and extraordinarily tasty treats, including multiple types of fleur de sel caramels and chocolate-covered fleur de sel caramels.... mmmmm (oh, how my dentist will love me).  
Only downside to all the uniqueness, is the pricey.  The goodies are costly.  No way around it.  But, once you've eaten a few pieces of happiness, price is a distant memory.
author: Roxanne C.

description: If I were rating the macaroons alone, this place would get 3 stars.  But I absolutely love their shop.  It is so cutely decorated and they have such a wide variety of sweets.  Girls would immediately fall in love with this place.  And they even have a macaroon happy hour ( 5-7 pm, M-F)-- a brilliant idea.  However, the macaroons from Patisserie Philipe just taste much better.  Regardless, all lovers of sweets should visit this shop at least once.
author: K V.

description:
A gem of a candy shop.  I was so happy to find some of my childhood favorite candies...they carry my all time favorite Dutch mints among other recognizable goodies from way back when.

I bought a box of fine milk chocolate cigars that Fidel Castro would be proud of!

Miette had me singing "I want Candddy" all the way home, all 70 feet of it.
author: Catrinel A.

description:
Très Bien!

Miette is the go to place for your afternoon sugar fix at Hayes Valley.   They offer a great selection of gourmet candies (taffy, licorice, caramels, chocolates) along with a few old time favorites (sugar daddies, tootsie rolls, jelly bellies, pixie sticks).  

In the confections section, the MACAROONS are absolutely divine!  They have a great flaky, outside with a chewy, fluffy inside that just melts in your mouth.  The flavor itself is intense (but not overpowering), complemented with just the right amount of sweetness.  Personal favorites: Rose and Hazelnut

Miette is conveniently  located right across from the park (the name escapes me now - but it has that giant copper monster statue?). So grab a treat and go enjoy the sun :)
author: Mischen C.

description:
I'd like to think my love affair with Miette is mutual. That could be some twisted rationalization for my guilt for the time and money I have spent in here, but gosh, does it get much cuter? I can take a lot of cute, and Miette can deliver the cute! 

Cute cupcakes, cute packaging, cute colors - and adorable, sweet (yes, a bad pun) girls behind the counter to help me make my next bad eating choice.

Also, I have an addiction that can only be found at Miette. I won't say exactly what it is, because my treat is occasionally sold out and I don't need any new competition, but let's just say I would happily sell my soul for a lifetime supply of said treats.

Did I mention the cupcakes?

And they have Zotz! Really, can you ask for anything more?
author: Hayesvalleygirl ..

description:
My awesome friend, P. and I met up to see a movie downtown. Beforehand, P. and his sister went to Miette and bought me a cupcake in the cutest little white box. They presented it to me at the movie and I wanted to save it to eat at home.

What I did, however, was leave it in the bathroom of the movie theatre. If you found it, please return!

Later, hubby and I dropped into the store and bought cupcakes and a lemon poundcake. I was sure to avoid public restrooms until I got these safely home.

The store is the cutest place I've ever seen and the cakes were delish!!
author: Kayla N.

description:
when i walk into this place i feel  as if some danny elfman score should be playing. The staff is über helpful, one attendant spent like 20 minutes blowing my mind with all the different types of licorice they had. I couldn't work my way to the "ultimate" if you make it let me know what happens.
I love how they have everything from super high end imported candy to the simplest lollipop. They have Mars bars for goodness sakes!
author: pascale p.

description: Did not like the macarons at all. Get much better one s at Chantal Guillon around the corner !
author: Vera A.

description:
No service problems here. Our party actually spent a fair amount of time chatting with the partner/co-owner that was working when we stopped by. Perhaps I was biased because she was so adorably sweet (no pun intended). 

A great selection of candies, perfect for that big kid in your life that needs a gift. A friend and I looked all over France for the Lion candy bar... only to find it here at Miette. 

Sampled the cupcake (Chocolate with Buttercream Frosting). The frosting was delicious, but the cupcake part itself seemed a bit dry... perhaps because it was 5:30 on a Friday afternoon. Apparently, the Gingerbread cupcake is the way to go (all $3 each).

Grab a cupcake and sit on the Octavia green or have them pack it up in a cute little stickered-box as a lovely pick-me-up for a friend.
author: Erin M.

description:
My first impression I had of Miette:  "Wow, everything's pink and damn, why does it smell like goat cheese?"  That didn't quite make sense that a candy store/bakery could smell like goat cheese but it did, and it was not pleasant.  I thought that maybe it was just me and perhaps something was amiss outside the store, but I kept smelling goat cheese the entire time I was there.  Weird, but there it was.

I had high hopes for Miette- I had heard about how great the cupcakes were and how cute the place was.  Miette is cute, but very sterile and a little too precious- I didn't particularly feel comfortable browsing through the store and everything just kinda screamed "Do not touch!" at me.  Half the time, I couldn't tell whether the candies were for sale or whether they were decorative display.  I wanted to try one of their cupcakes, but they looked surprisingly plastic in the case, and honestly I just didn't feel like paying $3 for those dainty treats.  I did take a gamble on their chocolate fleur de sel caramels...I wanted the plain, but apparently, Easter had wiped out their stocks.  I also bought some Italian gianduja chocolates, which were really difficult to get out of their glass jars- I had to tip the heavy things over to get to them and I really got zero help from the salespeople.  

Overall, Miette is a very grown-up candy store that just doesn't have the friendliness or coziness that I expected.  I liked that they had little tags throughout the star describing the different chocolates and candies, which helped me in my decision process.  3 stars for having some interesting candies, but I think they could do a lot more in helping customers feel comfortable and perhaps in expanding their stock.
author: Angela H.

description:
Fancy candy. Real easy on the eyes, pretty wallpaper, pretty candy in glass jars, pretty hand written notes that detail what kind of candy you are spying on. 

The place piled in soon after I got there - and the lovely Miette lady offered everyone a taster of the holland mints. YUM.

As a sucker for hand made caramels, I bought one of each flavor. I do hope Miette ventures into making fruit flavored caramels like the ones they have at Masa's. That would be a dream come true.

Oh and Miette does not sell too many chocolate covered treats, which is acutally quite refreshing. They have the most lovely marzipan shaped fawns - and I've never seen those before.
author: Judy L.

description:
Heaven! (If you had to pay to go there.) Frankly, I think this place is worth every penny. No, it's not your local candy shop that you pop into to soothe your sweet tooth, but it's the temple at which you pay homage to it. 

The rose geranium cotton candy is like nothing else.
author: Arwen O.

description:
Let me first begin by saying that my sweet tooth has been in a deep slumber for god knows how long. 


I hardly ever crave sweets. For ex) If you were to go back in time and take a glimpse into my room as a young'un, a week before Halloween, you'd easily find the previous year's Trick-or-Treat bag STILL chock-full of candy. I don't know what's wrong w/ me, but I tend to shy away from the sugar. However, this past weekend, my sweet tooth awoke w/ one bite of a Macademia Nut Macaroon!

Seeing as how there's so much hype over Miette's coveted macaroons, I thought I'd see what all the fuss was about and pick up a few since I was in the neighborhood. And to my surprise... I flipped my LID over these sweet lil' chewy treats! The sugar factor wasn't overwhelming and the Macademia Nut bits were a nice touch. I also tried their Chocolate Macaroons, which were just as satisfying. Now that I'm addicted, I couldn't be anymore thrilled to learn that they're taking over Moonstruck Chocolatier's space in the Marina. Now I can indulge in these puppies whenever I'm looking for a sugar fix!

If you're not into macaroons, then I'm sure you'll be won over by Miette's cakes. They look like a girl's dream cake! If I could, I'd buy one, set it in the middle of the dining room table, and gaze at it all day. Seriously. They're that adorable.

Extra bonus points go to Miette for their cute & charming design. From the store to the stickers to the paper bags to the website, Miette conveys the fact that they're in the know about maintaining good brand identity.


TIP: Stop by Miette if you're looking for something to top off your picnic lunch basket w/ (they've got cute, mini sized cake loaves and cupcakes!) or if you're putting together a gift basket. I'm planning on picking up a bunch of treats for my bed-ridden, pregnant friend!
author: Tiffany M.

description:
Lately, I've needed things that just make me happy and bring me joy.

Walking into this place gives me great joy.

It is very difficult to feel down when you're surrounded by candy in a sort of Marie Antoinette pastel paradise.

Full disclosure - I have yet to actually buy anything there - frankly, I'm just a voyeur.
author: Anna H.

description:
I wish I never came here.  Wish I never saw that pink sign on the corner pointing to your direction.

It's like, punishment...TORTURE!  It's terrible!!!  F you, you apricot buttercream frosted yellow cake CUPCAKE!  How can you be so damn delectable, and moist in your seemingly innocent appearance with your tiny little yellow sugar candy flower so perfectly placed at the very center of the piped apricot goodness! 

And the table in the middle of the store, you with your Italian Caffarel Puro Cioccolato Gianduia.  I was a recovering hazelnut/choco addict.  But NO!  Had to fall for the pretty yellow wrapper with the tiny flowers.  I haven't had a piece of chocolate that's ever melted on my tongue quite like that.  I 'bought one to try'.  Now I have to drive back and ask for you, BASTARD.  I hate you.  I hate you so much I love you.  

And then I find out...THEY DO WEDDING FAVORS!?!  Tell me, how I can have a wedding now that I risk jeopardizing fitting into an elegant Monique Lhuillier.  You're dangerous!!!  Decorated in my favorite colors, with beautiful green crown molding, fit enough for 'Amelie Poulain' to stop by...vintage jars filled with colorful, dainty, I-don't-know-whats (but now I'm on a mission to go back and find out).  For a Hayes Valley store, the lady working the counter (Ms. Tess) was super nice...

Bah!  That's what I get for being a sucker for chichi persuasions.
author: Meesh K.

description: The candy is lovely and the presentation is beautiful but the lack of general courtesy is what really sticks in my mind.  Even though I like the product the fact that the staff cannot be bothered to help you would prevent me from going back.  I went out of my way to visit the store to buy a particular item.  The store had just opened and there were no other customers inside.  Not only was I not greeted after milling about for a bit looking for a product, the staff was dismissive and when I asked about the item, the salesman offered a cold, "try downtown at the Ferry building."  He did not offer to call the other location and when I asked if he had a suggestion for replacement his reply was a curt "no."  No need to ever go back there.
author: J B.

description: Picked up a couple cakes for a party from here and the girls working were so friendly and helpful.  One of the cakes was custom ordered over the phone and they were friendly throughout the whole process.  The store also has a lot of different candies and sweets.
author: Gordon C.

description:
Did you know that Miette has a younger sister.  No, not the one in the Marina or the one in the Ferry building.  In fact, she's not American, she might even be a half sister ... no, she's actually just a celeb look-a-like.

While on a trip to Ottawa, Canada recently, I stumbled upon a shop called The Candy Store - you must click on the link, as it is eerie -  (http://thecandystoreottawa.ca/)  Recently opened, I knew that I had seen a similar color scheme, wall paper design and overall look and feel until it dawned on me - Miette in Hayes Valley in my hometown of San Francisco!

While each shop is unrelated to one another, I could not help to think that the Ottawa shop owner must have thought that her store would never be discovered by a San Franciscan wandering around a random little neighborhood in the upper northern reaches of Canada.

What did Chales Caleb Colton say?  "Imitation is the sincerest form of flattery".
author: Rafael R.

description:
#49 on the Big Eat SF
Ginger snaps

aDORable little place. candy lover's dream.

the ginger snaps are awesome. but beware - i had them nice and snappy one day. another day a friend bought a pack and they were a bit stale (still tasted great though). so if you get the latter, try again!
author: S V.

description:
Love their macaroons, especially the vanilla and the hazelnut.  Will be trying Paulette soon to compare but Miette's is so far my favorite macaroon in the city.  They also have really good small cakes.  

One thing I WOULD NOT recommend is that cupcake that looks like it has white marshmallow on top.  Not great.
author: Courtney N.

description:
Handmade Carmels (so yummy!)
The craziest Licorice known to man (from salty to sweet)
Sweet bites from the Patisserie (wonderful macaroons)
and the girls working are so friendly, you never know when they will offer a sample of this jelly or that gummy... really a fun cute place to get your sugar high on...
author: Joy C.

description: Super cute store, super overpriced merchandise.  I'd say on average they're charging 50% more than you'd pay at other fine candy stores for the same chocolate bars.  Honestly, I love the look of the place, but I had trouble finding any candy I really wanted to pay those kinds of prices for.
author: Jessica N.

description:
Tres, tres adorable! This store is straight out of a parisian inspired children's story. It must be! Marzipan in the shape of camembert, violet drops, green tea lozenges, hazelnut chocolate bites so thick and rich I sprained my tongue. 

What fresh clean faces for this neighborhood. J'adore Miette!

From classic european treats to contempory candy bars, you will find something sweet for whichever tooth is a'hankering.
author: Jerkey J.

description:
Treat yourself to the hayes valley experience... hit Blue Bottle for Coffee, and Miette for somethin' sweet. Gingerbread and Old Fashioned cupcakes are wonderful. When in stock, the Sospiri (italian marzipan) is one of the greatest things i've ever eaten (for real). Caramels are excellent, the licorice is great but be careful of the salmiac (some are very intense). All the macaroons are good too, esp. the Pistachio. Great selection of gummy candy too: try the Grapefruit Slices (white or pink) -- almost as delightful as the ladies serving you!

No Oompa Loompas necessary.
author: Ryan F.

description: If Willy Wonka were female and not crazy (okay, maybe a LITTLE crazy), this would be the storefront he envisioned. Draped in pinks and whites and a confetti of cookies, candies, and every sweet imaginable, this is definitely a sugar-fiend's dream. Just be weary: Given the inflated prices, this is definitely a grown up's candy store for a grown up's wallet.
author: Valerie C.

description:
It is true that many things in here can be found elsewhere.  But just as many can't.  For instance, they have well over a dozen different kinds of licorice.  Most appear to be Scandanavian imports, even some of the salted ones that confuse the American palate.  (The ones I bought were sweet and delicious though.)

Anyway, maybe it's better to develop a sweet tooth for expensive candies rather than than slumming it with Hersheys and the like.  Those things are far too easy access.  Miette can be saved for special occasions.
author: Jim C.

description:
Cuteness quotient here is through the roof, almost unbearably adorable. The cupcakes are so pretty, it seems unlikely that they'll taste any good. Oh, but they do! 
I feel prettier just standing in the store.
author: Purnima M.

description:
Freshly spun cotton candy?  Oh yeah, not that crapfest they have at the movie theaters, but the real deal?  Count me in.  Sometimes the kid in me needs a bit more fuel and what better way than spun sugar?

For the more adventurous, they've also got a bacon chocolate bar.  I have no idea what it tastes like, I like my bacon as a savory, not a sweet.  What?  Call me old-fashioned.
author: Anonymouse C.

description:
Does Candyland really exist? Yes'm and it's called Miette Confiserie. 

Miette puts a smile on my face no matter how crappy my day is going. Every time I walk in, I'm greeted with a big smile by any of the staff members. When they first opened, I came in and chatted one of the girls up about how much I missed Canadian candy bars from my motherland. She ran into the back and grabbed me a Coffee crisp and Aero bar and when I offered to pay for them, she said that I could have them for free. I admittedly teared up a bit because I was so grateful to her for giving me back a piece of my home in two little candybars.
author: Clarissa S.

description:
Yes, it's cute and it's pricey. But they have Schoolkrijt licorice from Holland! YUUUUUMMMM! I can't do much better price-wise in the Bay Area for this addictive candy.

And of course they have their yummy parisian cookies and their cuppy cakes. Some of the candy there is too normal, but you can get some good European stuff that's hard to find here and it's fresh. Try Malteasers if you like Whoppers.
author: Dana B.

description:
My favorite place in the city to buy sweets. The owners are exceptionally nice and always willing to help you sample every type of licorice in the store until you find just the right one. Or whatever treat you desire.

I would have to say that the imported dragees with a subtle vanilla sugar coating and both the San Francisco made nougat with orange rind and pistachio bits as well as the Fleur de Sel caramels are the best items in the store.
author: Angela K.

description:
I pressed my nose against the glass like that little boy in Willy Wonka.

Surely, there must be someone in there singing "Candy Man" (the kahimi karie version?) as they straighten up the shelf. 
 
And I got a gift set for my birthday. Rococo chocolates (which I've loved and give credit to Bell'occhio for bringing them to our beloved city in the first place)!  Jelly beans!  Love! 

I love their cola bottles. Can't wait to try the rootbeer barrels and gumdrops.
author: Ms. Q.

description: LOVE this place! The pastries are uber yummy and the store is beautiful. We went twice we loved it so much
author: Tacia C.

description:
I always tell people this is the candy store I imagined in my dreams when I was 9 years old. Pitch-perfect with the wallpaper, the glass jars full of colorful treats, nice ladies in cute outfits working at the counter. The whole fantasy, realized.

On top of that, they have so many fine and handmade chocolates and candies that appeal to a grown-up tastebud. It's the best of all worlds!
author: Celeste S.

description:
This place is dangerously awesome!  Its worlds away from grabbing a snickers at 7-11! At first you get sticker shock because a lot of the candy is expensive, but then how much are you really buying?  They will let you sample a lot of the candys so just ask.  They will even help you shop for just the perefct candy that you want with great acuracy.  The staff are very friendly and even remember people by name and teh candy they like.

My favorites are the kukaburo red licorice and the dragees suger coated almonds.
author: christopher r.

description:
Gingerbread Cupcakes!!  Nom nom nom

I make a point to shove one of their cupcakes in my face every so often.  And while I'm there I end up picking up some old school zots.  and jelly beans.  and lollipops.  and licorice.  and caramels...

Cons: Pricey- but seriously worth it.  And while most of the staff is as delightful as their candy, at least one staffer clearly isn't on the same sugar high.
author: Nicole K.

description:
Two thoughts:
1. This is the sweet boutique of my daydreams.
2. The Poco Dolce bittersweet chocolate they carry is the way to my heart. 

(The almond coconut square with grey sea salt is enough to make me move to San Francisco)

Think on these things. And then pick up some Poco Dolce as a personal pick-me up, peace offering, house warming tithing, or romantic gesture. 

Please consider mailing me a box. 
...just thought I'd put it out there.
author: Melanie K.

description:
Super cute.  Great selection of licorice.  You gotta try the chocolate with licorice that look like m&m's.  
I much prefer the $3 Endangered Species Chocolate Bar from my local grocer to the $10 dollar one here.
Best for gifts for people (great packaging), and dates.
I can see how the service could be spotty.
All in all, it's worth it to treat yourself sometimes, but too expensive to make it a habit.
Don't try to lick the wallpaper.
author: Robert W.

description: My absolute favorite candy shop. You step in, and you're transported back to a delicate and charming childhood that you may never have experienced yourself. With carefully curated tables of sweets made locally and abroad, you can spend hours feasting your eyes on the chocolate bars, taffies and gummies. If you're looking for a great hostess gift, try the gingersnaps, chocolate chip cookies, or one of the shortbreads (lemon, walnut, or lavender). At the counter, you'll find a line of nostalgic candies that no doubt get the most comments. My personal favorite is what lies behind the glass case (and in the glass jars): freshly baked cupcakes, mini cakes (like their signature old-fashioned and tomboys), and macarons. Those who like the traditional macaron a La Duree might not love Miette's take, but I prefer these over any other I've tried. They are cakier, and the flavor in the cream-based varieties (vanilla, rose, pistachio etc.) is much more subtle.
